Witness is 38 years old and married. She has two children who are ages 20 and 14.

loans.use: To buy more medicine for her pharmacy.

loans.name: Chadulu H Group

texts.en:
Josephine has been a vegetable seller in the Ipagala neighborhood of Dodoma for four years. She currently earns an average monthly profit of $175. She is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more inventory for her business, increase her sales, and pay school fees for her children.

Josephine is 37 years old, married, and has five children who are between the ages of 28 and 6. She also takes care of another child. She will be sharing this loan with her fellow group members Sabina, Colletha, Zainabu, and Pili. Each woman also has her own small business in Iringa.

loans.use: To buy more vegetables to sell in her business.

loans.name: Chadulu H Group

texts.en:
Enitha has been a vegetable and charcoal seller in the Ipagala neighborhood of Dodoma for one year. She is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more inventory to grow her business and pay school fees for her children.

Enitha is 40 years old and married with six children who are between the ages 7 and 27. She will be sharing this loan with her fellow group members Evodia, Lucy, Salma, and Verian. Each woman also has her own small business in Dodoma.

loans.use: To buy more vegetables to sell in her business.

loans.name: Chadulu H Group

texts.en:
Beatrice M. has been selling drinks in the Ipagala neighborhood of Dodoma for one year. She is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more materials to grow her business.

Beatrice is 32 years old and single with two children, who are four and nine. She also takes care of other two additional dependents. She will be sharing this loan with her fellow group members Elica, Hawa, Christina, and Maria. Each woman also has her own small business in Dodoma.

loans.use: To more drinks to sell in her business.

loans.name: Kisasa B Group

texts.en:
Rebeca has owned a small charcoal store and sold vegetables in the Ipagala neighborhood of Dodoma for twenty years. She is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more inventory to grow her business. She would then be able to pay school fees for her children and provide more food for her family.

Rebeca is 38 years old and married with three children, who are between the ages of 4 and 14. She will be sharing this loan with her fellow group members Jema, Neema, Rehema, and Pili. Each woman also has her own small business in Dodoma.

loans.use: To buy more inventory for her business.

loans.name: Safia Parveen M.ramzan Group

texts.en:
Safia parveen baji is a 33 year old lady who resides in a city named Borewala in Pakistan. She owns a two room brick house and has been living in it for the past 18 years. Naseem baji couldn’t get an education because of her poor financial condition. She got married at the age of 20. Her husband's name is M. and he has a grocery shop. Most of the people in the community come to him to buy groceries. Safia baji has four children: two sons and two daughters. All of her children are getting an education. Safia baji and Mr.Ramzan decided to share the expenses. Safia baji sews clothes and makes embroidered dresses and uses the profit to pay her children’s school fees and Mr. Ramzan bears the house expenses. She is applying for a loan to buy groceries for her husband’s grocery shop.

Safia baji is the leader of a group with a few more members. Razia baji wants a loan to buy wires and switch boards for her electric shop. Zubaida baji wants a loan to buy an auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle). Fozia baji wants a loan to buy repair tools for her motor workshop. Tahira yasmeen baji wants a loan to buy sanitary supplies (water pipes) to resell.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy more groceries to sell in the grocery shop.

loans.name: Eustaquia

texts.en:
Eustaquia has been a member of our microcredit program for a long time, and she’s requesting her third cycle loan in order to reinforce her small business. The entrepreneur sells sheets metal in her neighborhood in order to sustain her family of 7 people.

Eustaquia explains that metal prices have shot up over the last 6 months, and she doesn’t have enough money to stock her business. She hopes that with this loan, she’ll be able to get back on track with her activity, and improve her family’s living conditions.

loans.use: Purchase sheet metal for a small business.

loans.name: Landing

texts.fr: Landing est un jeune couturier qui résident à Boucotte Centre, un des grands quartiers de Ziguinchor. Il demande ce crédit pour accroître ses revenus en cette fin d'année 2008 uù la demande est forte en prêt à porter.
texts.en:
Landing is a young tailor who lives in Boucotte Centre, one of the large neighborhoods in Ziguinchor. He's seeking this loan to increase his profits, since ready-to-wear demand is high during this time of year.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To bolster his business

loans.name: Saem's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Saem T. is a group leader of six people, all of whom live in Phum Da Vige in Kampong Chhnang Province. She is a farmer who cultivates both rice and vegetables. She also sells Khmer noodles. Mrs. Saem T. does not have enough money to hire laborers to work on her farm, so she decided to ask for a loan to hire laborers. Her husband, Mr. Ki Savy, is a soldier who makes a small income to support the household. Mrs. Saem T. is 29 years old and the mother of two children  who attend the local school. 

All the members in this group loan are end-of-term loans so they are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK’s main product because they are the most beneficial to Cambodia’s poor. EoT loans allow borrowers to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK’s clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To hire laborers

loans.name: Abou

texts.fr: Abou L. est un bijoutier trés connu au marché central (Boucotte) de Ziguinchor. Ce pére de famille travaille dans ce secteur depuis une vingtaine d'années. Grâce à ses revenus, il assume les charges faliliales. Il sollicite ce prêt pour renforcer son business.
texts.en:
Abou L. is a well-known jeweler in the central market (Boucotte) of Ziguinchor. This father of a family has been working in this field for approximately 20 years. Thanks to his revenues, he provides for his family. He's seeking this loan to bolster his business.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To bolster his business

loans.name: Escolastica

texts.en:
When Escolastica took her first loan from FSMA, she had just started a small business of selling used clothing in her neighborhood. She had a hankering to operate a fruit and vegetable stand, as her clothing business was not profitable. With patience, hard work and sacrifice, Escolastica was able to reach this goal and she says that she feels proud and happy that she’d been able to use her loan wisely. Paying to educate her two children is now less stressful for her, although she still needs to increase her income to cover the household expenses.

With this second loan, Escolastica will purchase a large variety of fruits to add to her inventory. She hopes that her business will allow her to buy a small house someday.

loans.use: Purchase fresh fruits to keep operating her business.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more rice for resale

loans.name: Dilshad Akhtar M.yaseen Group

texts.en:
Dilshad Akhtar is a 40-year-old married woman who lives in Vehari, Pakistan. She is not educated, but she believes that education is essential to every walk of life. Her husband, M., sells a Punjabi food called "dahi bhala." He has 22 years of experience in this business. 

Dilshad baji has two children, one son and one daughter. Her son supports his father in his food business. Her daughter is in 2nd standard (4th grade). She and her husband work hard for their children, because their daughter wants to be a doctor. 

Dilshad baji is a seamstress who sews clothes. She has 15 years of experience in this business. She successfully repaid the first loan that she took from Asasah, a microfinance institute in Pakistan. Now she is applying for a new loan to buy spices and vegetables to make more dahi bhala to sell. 

Dilshad baji is the leader of a five-member loan group in her locality. Najma baji wants a loan to buy a sewing machine for her sewing business. Haleema baji wants a loan to buy tools for her motor workshop. Sonia baji wants a loan to buy cosmetics and creams for her parlor. Rashida baji wants a loan to buy tools to repair watches. 

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

Note: "Baji," which means "older sister" is a term of respect for women in Pakistan.

loans.use: To buy spices and vegetables for a food business

loans.name: Chroeb's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Chroeb E. is the president of a village bank of twelve people who all live in Toeuk Chenh Village in Kampong Chhnang Province. All the members will use the loan for different purposes. Mrs. Chroeb E. is a basket maker and seller who can make a small income to support her family. Her husband, Mr. Chuon Pov, is a traditional musician who plays the music during wedding ceremonies, funerals, and parties. Although Mrs. Chroeb E. and her husband try to work hard, they still live in poor conditions and in an old house. In order to improve their standard of living, Mrs. Chroeb E. decided to ask for a loan to build a new house for her family. Mrs. Chroeb E. is 32 years old and the mother of five childrE., four of whom are attending the local school while the youngest one is just two years old. Mrs. Thuo S. does not come to take a loan but her husband is, so he is presented in the picture instead of his wife.

This is a village bank loan consisting of mainly end-of-term loans. SevE. members have end-of-term loans and the rest have monthly payment loans. They are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK’s main product because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia’s poor. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK’s clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To ask for a loan to build a new house for her family.

loans.name: Zareena Nasir Hussain Group

texts.en:
My name is Zareena Bibi and I reside in a city named Vehari, Pakistan.  I own a two-room brick house in this city where I and my family have lived for the last 30 years. 

My husband name is N. H., and he has a quilt selling business.  He has been selling quilts for the past 8 years.  

I have three kids: one daughter and two sons.  My elder son works with his father and sells quilts in other cities.  Both of them buy the quilts from a famous city, Multan.  My younger son is 16 years old and my daughter is 5 years old.  I perform my duties as a mother and as a wife as well.  

Along with these responsibilities I perform my duty as a woman also.  I believe in myself.  I make the warm quilts with my hands and hand them over to my son.  In cities, people have the tendency to buy handmade items.  I made three quilts in a month.  My effort returned to my family in the shape of good income. 

My family is very happy with me, which makes me more confident.  I am applying for a loan to buy warm quilts along with materials (cotton and thread) for making quilts. 

I am a group leader of a few more members in my locality.  Zahida Baji and Ameena Baji each want a loan to buy quilts to resell.  Shahla Shahzadi Baji wants a loan to buy calling cards to resell. 

This is a group loan.  The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business.  The members mutually guarantee one another's loans.  If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy materials for making warm quilts

loans.name: Torn's Group

texts.en:
The village bank, which is located in Phum Soupy village in Kampong Chhnang province, consists of eighteen people who will each use the loan that they obtain for different purposes.  

Mr. Torn S. is a village bank president who has been selected by the members.  He owns a small grocery store in the local market.  Since this business is going well, he wants to expand it.  So, he decided to ask for a loan to buy more grocery products for his inventory.  His wife, Mrs. Yun Soky, helps him in the current business. 

Mr. Torn S. is 43 years old and the father of five children who are all attending the local school.
 
All the members in this group loan are end-of-term loans, so they are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term.  End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK’s main product because they are the most beneficial to Cambodia’s poor.  It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to.  Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term.  Almost all of AMK’s clients make their payments on time.  AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To buy more grocery products for his inventory.

loans.name: Safia Nazir Ahmad Group

texts.en:
Safia baji is 42, married, and lives in a two-room, brick house in Vehari, Pakistan with her family. Her husband, N. A., has been a cobbler (his family business) for 20 years. Safia baji has one son who is 12 years old and reads in 5th standard. Safia baji is a housewife who helps her husband in his shoe-making business also. She pastes the heel under the shoes and helps complete customer orders. Their son helps when he can. Safia is requesting a loan to buy more materials (leather, nails and color) to help their business.

She is a group leader, and there are 3 other members in her group: Rafiqan baji and Shamim akhtar baji each request a loan to buy medicines to resell. Haseena baji requests a loan to buy inventory for her grocery shop. 

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy materials for making shoes

loans.name: Rafoat

texts.en:
Rafoat is a hard-working woman. She is married and has three children. For the past 17 years, Rafoat has dedicated herself to selling office supplies and books for schoolboys. Her husband was employed with a construction company, but his contract ended. With her husband’s income missing, bills started to pile up and Rafoat decided to start her own business to generate her own income to try to fill the gap. She likes what she sells and has developed a stable enterprise.

Rafoat has requested a loan of $600 USD to help purchase a new supply of items to sell. She commits to paying her loan back within 12 months. This is an important matter for this family's well-being. Please help Rafoat's business grow. She truly appreciates your generosity.

More about Tajikistan

Tajikistan is perhaps best known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road; the end of Alexander the Great's rule; and its great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Ibn Sina (Avicenna), Firdousi, Omar Haiyam, Jomi, Mavlavi Rumi and many others. The country is home to epic mountain passes, communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. Today it remains a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war that ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R. further damaged its already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

About IMON International

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj.

loans.use: Purchase office supplies to sell

loans.name: Mukaramakhon

texts.en:
Mukaramakhon describes herself as a enterprising girl with the goal to achieve successes in the future. She decided to start a sewing business to help her family with household expenses a year ago. She started out helping a woman who ran a tailoring shop. Being very nimble, she learned tailoring and soon began running her own business at the tailoring shop. It has gone very well since then, and she has been able to grow the business.

Mukaramakhon is requesting a loan of $600 USD to purchase materials so she can fulfill her customers' requests. The end of the year is fast approaching, and that is when demand is at its highest. She plans to repay the loan within 12 months. Mukaramakhon and her family are very grateful for your support in helping grow this business and move ahead.

More about Tajikistan

Tajikistan is perhaps best known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road; the end of Alexander the Great's rule; and the birthplaces of the great Persian poet Rudaki and the most famous Islamic philosopher, Ibn Sina (Avicenna). The country is home to epic mountain passes, communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. Today it remains a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war that ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R. further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj.

loans.use: To purchase materials for sewing national dresses

loans.name: Sayed Mohammad

texts.en:
Sayed M. lives in district 8 of Kabul, Afghanistan. His house is near the Kabul River. He is married and has two children. He has a cosmetics shop and he needs money to make his shop larger.

M. is requesting an individual loan of 30000 Afghans for a term of 12 months to expand his business. He plants to buy new cosmetics for his shop to attract additional clients and help his family.

M. is very happy with this loan process, especially for those who want to start a new business. He hopes to continue his partnership with both AFSG and Kiva, and he would like to thank all lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional cosmetics to sell

loans.name: Alia M. Malik Group

texts.en:
Alia baji is a 25-year-old lady and resides in a city named Vehari, Pakistan. She has been living in this city for the past 5 years. She belongs to a poor family. She couldn’t attend school because her parents couldn’t bear her education expenses due to their low income. Her husband name is M. M. and he has a quilt-selling business. He does this work with his brother.

Alia baji’s mother taught her the art of sewing clothes before her marriage. This art has helped her after marriage: she started helping her husband in making warm quilts. She is applying for a loan to buy material (cloth, cotton, and thread) to expand her husband’s business.

She is the group leader for a few more women from her locality. Mukhtaran baji and Gulshan baji and Nazia baji each want a loan to buy quilts to re-sell. Naziran baji wants a loan to buy leather and nails for her shoe-making business.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy materials for making warm quilts

loans.name: Khurshed

texts.en:
Khurshed R. is 20 years old. He is a young boy with a great desire to get ahead in life. Khurshed has been running a pharmacy business for 4 years together with his loving mother, pictured in the photo. Currently he is working in the city polyclinics in the dispensary.

Khurshed loves his work; he likes to help people and is ready to consult with the patients purchasing medicines in his store and those who could not find the required goods in his store. During all the years of his work, Khurshed was dreaming of opening his own drug store and saving money for this. He hopes that someday he can realize his dream.

Now Khurshed has requested $ 600 US Dollars for a term of 5 months. Khurshed is a client of IMON and has a positive credit history. Now he promises to repay the loan promptly and thanks everyone supporting him.

loans.use: Purchasing medicines for re-sale

loans.name: Zahar

texts.en:
Zahar is the son of M. S.. He lives in Kabul, Afghanistan. His house is near the Kabul River and he is 24 years old. He is single and has three sisters and two brothers.

Zahar has a car part shop and has some good numbers of customers and he import different kinds of parts of car for his customers and he need for some money here and wants to expand his business.

 He has requested an individual loan of 50000 Afghans for the term of 12 months to make  his shop larger and complete his necessary materials to continue his business so he makes a good monthly income for his family. He is sure that after this loan he can do it.

Zahar is very happy with this procedure of small loans and thanks all lenders, specially Kiva.

loans.use: To expand his shop

loans.name: Paa

texts.en:
Paa K. is 42 years old.  He is single and the father of one child who is in school.  He had an unexpected divorce, so he had to take his child and look after him on his own.  

Paa is very hard working and resourceful to his family.  He trades in charcoal in Abeka of Accra in his neighborhood.  Charcoal is a very popular source of energy for cooking in almost all Ghanaian traditional homes.  Paa obtains his supply of charcoal from the surrounding villages of Accra.  Such places include the Afram plains and others.  He retails the charcoal to his customers in the market place of Abeka. 

He wants to use the loan to buy a bulk supply of charcoal to increase his inventory.  He hopes the loan will enable him to increase his savings and pay his child's educational fees.  

He belongs to the community group called Vibrant Trust Group.  In this group, members guarantee one another as social collateral to repay the loan.  Paa wants help for his business.  He says he wants to help his child before leaving earth.

loans.use: Paa wants the loan to buy more bags of charcoal before the raining season.

loans.name: Mutaramkhon

texts.en:
V. Mutaramkhon is an enterprising woman with a big desire for improving the quality of life of her family.  She is married with 3 children. 

Two years ago, she started offering her services as a seamstress to her neighbors and acquaintances.  She began this business because she did not have a job and she needed to find an activity so that she could support her husband with family expenses.  She works in tailoring shop where she produces national dresses for women. 

Now, all of her children are going to school.  She wishes that her children will be able to continue their education.  That is the reason why she needs to continue growing her business. 

She asks for a loan of $600 USD that will be invested in buying supplies to increase her production and cover her customers' demands.  She commits herself to return back the amount in 12 months.  Please help this family to improve their quality of their life by contributing to the growth of Mutaramkhon’s business.  They will sincerely thank you for it.

loans.use: Purchasing fabrics for sewing women's national dresses.

loans.name: Thuo's Group

texts.en:
The village bank, which consists of seventeE. people is located in Phum Soupy village in Kampong Chhnang province.  Mrs. Thuo C. is a village bank president. 

She is a basket maker and also a pig breeder.  Since the second business is going well, she wants to expand it, so she decided to ask for a loan to buy three more piglets for breeding.  Her husband, Mr. Leng Run, is a laborer who can make a small income to support the family.  

Mrs. Thuo C. is 21 years old and the mother of two childrE. who are both too yoU. to work or study because they are at the ages of five months and two years old.  Mr. Dieb P. did not come to take the loan with his wife is, so she is presented in the picture instead.
   
All the members in this group loan are end-of-term loans, so they are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term.  End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK’s main product because they are the most beneficial to Cambodia’s poor.  It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to.  Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term.  Almost all of AMK’s clients make their payments on time.  AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To buy three more piglets for breeding.

loans.name: John

texts.en:
He is a creative, innovative, dynamic fashion designer and time bound when it comes to work.  John K. is his name, and he is 39 years old.  He is married and the father of two kids.  Currently, the kids are in school. 

He has been sewing for nineteen years and not just sewing, but he also attached professionalism to his work.  He is a specialist in male and female wears.  His skills and designs are of a class.  He sews various kinds of styles that give his customers new looks, like kaba and slit, wedding dresses, funeral clothes, men’s designer shirts, and any African style of dress you can think of.  He also sells men’s slippers which gives him extra income to support his family.  

He wants to use the loan to buy increased supplies of sewing materials like linen, threads, thimbles, etc. to increase his output and efficiency as well as his slippers.  John hopes to increase his savings to provide his children with a quality education. 

He is a member of the community group called “Vibrant”.  In this group, members guarantee one another as social collateral to access loan and provide support to one another to repay the loan.

loans.use: Young and energetic John needs the loan to buy thimbles, threads, slippers, linen and an electric sewing machine for efficiency.

loans.name: Mani Dalair Khan Group

texts.en:
My name is Mani and I reside in a city named Vehari, Pakistan.  I have six members in my family.  I have been living in this city for the past 25 years. 

I am an uneducated woman, but my parents made me a skillful woman who can fight and make herself stable in every circumstance.  I am proud of my parents.  

My husband has a quilt selling business.  It’s a high demand business in Vehari city.  I make warm quilts at home and my husband sells them in different shops and markets and earns profit.  My sons are enrolled in a local school to get an education.  I am applying for a loan to buy materials (cloth, cotton and thread) for making more quilts to resell. 

I am a group leader of a few more women in my locality.  Sumera Baji and Zareena Baji each want a loan to buy sewing machines for sewing clothes.  Farzana Baji and Shakeela Baji each want a loan to buy quilts to resell. 

This is a group loan.  The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business.  The members mutually guarantee one another's loans.  If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy materials for making warm quilts

loans.name: Inomjon

texts.en:
D. Inomjon has dedicated much effort to the business of agriculture for 18 years already.  He has 0.8 hectares of land where produces different kinds of vegetables.  He also has a lot of apricot trees on his land. 

He gets a rich harvest every year from his land.  From the savings of his land he could arrange the weddings of his two children.  He also plants different kinds of feeds for animals such as corn, hay, etc.  

Currently, Inomjon is asking for a loan of 4000 Somoni ($1200 USD) in order to purchase fuels and lubricants, mineral fertilizer and also saplings for expanding his fruit garden.  Inomjon is very confident that he will be awarded this loan and assures you that the money will be repaid in time with no violations.

loans.use: Purchasing fuels and lubricants, mineral fertilizer and saplings

loans.name: Cynthia

texts.en:
Cee, as she is popularly called by her numerous customers, is a 42 year-old local restaurant operator.  She is married and blessed with three children.  With income from her business, she has provided for one of her children to graduate from senior high school.

In her restaurant, she prepares and sells local foods like “banku” - rice with stew.  Banku is prepared from milled maize grains and is taken with hot pepper or soup.  Apart from this, she also prepares pastries like meat pies and cakes.  

Cynthia says that the prices of raw materials have gone up significantly and she needs the support of a loan to enable her to meet her production expenditures.  She wants to use the loan to buy more raw materials like bags of maize, flour, margarine, sugar, meat, fish, vegetables, and firewood.

Cynthia is a member of a group called Success Trust Group.  In this group, members guarantee and provide support to one another to repay the loan.  Her picture was taking when she was visited at her business site.

loans.use: Cynthia wants the loan to buy raw materilas like flour, margarine, maize, firewood, meat, fish, etc.

loans.name: Komil

texts.en:
For the past 6 years, Komil has worked in agriculture and the raising of animals.  He raises cows which he cares for greatly since, thanks to them, he can cover his household expenses through the milk which he sells in the mornings.  Komil showed us his animals with great happiness as his cows were about to be vaccinated against the various sicknesses that affect that type of livestock.  

For Komil, it is very important to work his land and raise his animals, which is why he is currently seeking a loan in order to purchase another cow so that his wife can make more milk and sell it in the local markets.  That will help his family to generate additional income.  We appreciate your support for Komil’s projects.

To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing of cattle and small cattle to expand the business.

loans.name: Mohammad Nasim

texts.en:
Mohammad Nasim is 27 years old and he lives in district 8 of Kabul, Afghanistan.  His house is near the Afghan Hotel.  He is single and has a shop in which he sells different kinds of things like drinks, cookies and so on.

He has requested an individual loan of 7000 Afghans for a term of 12 months to complete his stocks and to attract more customers to his business because he is new to this business and wants to buy some other things for his shop.

Nasim is very happy with this loan of Kiva, and especially for the AFSG, which helps poor people, and thanks to all lenders.

loans.use: To complete his stocks and grow his business

loans.name: Rafiqan Noor Muhammad Group

texts.en:
My name is Rafiqan, and I am a 52 year old married lady.  I have resided in a city named Vehari, Pakistan for the past 30 years.  I have no children.  My husband doesn’t criticize me about children.  He is a carpenter by profession, with 20 years of experience.  

He has a shop in Vehari where he displays his furniture.  Mostly, people of Vehari come to his shop and give orders for furniture.  I am a seamstress and sew clothes for my neighbors.  We have a good reputation in the community, and in the market as well.  

I have successfully repaid my two loans, which I took from Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan).  Now, I am applying for a loan to buy materials (wood, glue and nails) to make more furniture to resell.

I have some more members in my group.  Zaitoon Baji wants a loan to buy a sewing machine for sewing clothes.  Alveena Baji wants a loan to buy scrap for her scrap business.  Rukhsana Baji wants a loan to buy vegetables to resell. 

This is a group loan.  The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business.  The members mutually guarantee one another's loans.  If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy materials for making furniture

loans.name: Akbarali

texts.en:
Akbarali is 51 years old and lives with his wife and 4 chidlren.  He is a humble farmer dedicated to producing such fruits as apricots, peaches, pears, etc.  He also produces feed for the animals inside his land.  This is why he has to leave early in the morning, and it takes time to go back home too. 

When he sees the harvest of his land, it comforts him and wants to harvest even more.  However, in order to do that he needs to invest large amounts of money.  He knows that with a larger harvest, he will have better results, and the fruit has to be of better quality in order to get more income from the sales.  

Aside from cultivating his land, Akbarali is also engaged in livestock.  Currently, he has 8 sheep.  He wants to increase his production and purchase more sheep to breed.  That’s the reason that he applied to IMON International for a loan of 4000 Somoni ($1200 USD) for the term of 10 months. 
 
More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is perhaps best known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road; the end of Alexander the Great's rule; and it’s famous great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets such as: Rudaki, Ibn Sina (Avicenna), Firdousi, Omar Haiyam, Jomi, Mavlavi Rumi and many others.  

The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC.  And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.
 
But, Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics.  The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy.  In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable.  These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia.  

While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty. 

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition.  Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need.  To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing of saplings and sheep

loans.name: Costa Alegre Group

texts.es:
Este comité se formó a través de la Sra. Maria P., quien se entero del programa e invitó a sus vecinas a participar de éste. Sus vecinas y amigas aceptaron ya que tuvo gran aceptación por los valores que difunde e impulsa el programa. Este es un comité sólido luego de afrontar muchas dificultades durante estos ciclos, superaron los conflictos por medio de la comunicación. 
Costa Alegre Poty es un comité muy sólido de señoras comprometidas con el trabajo. Cada integrante posee una actividad comercial específica que realiza con la finalidad de recaudar dinero para el sustento de sus familias. Estas actividades son:
1	María P.	Despensa
2	Fidencia Ruíz	Venta de Verduras 
3	Mirna A.	Despensa
4	Mariza A.	Despensa
5	Lucia S.	Venta de Leche
6	Damacia B.	Despensa
7	Anuncia M.	Venta de Carbón
8	Idalina López	Venta de Verduras
9	Ana C.	Despensa
10	Alicia A.	Venta de Queso
11	Laura S.	Venta de Leche
12	Sebastiana G.	Mecánica Dental
13	Ana M.	Venta de bollos
14	Edith O.	Venta de lencería
15	Maria C.	Venta de cigarros


Reciben de crédito un promedio de Gs. 500.000  cada una, ellas invierten en la compra de leche, compra de azúcar, harina, semillas, compra de carbón, lencería, tabacos, pastas dentarias, dientes artificiales, mandioca, bebidas gaseosas, semillas, etc.
texts.en:
This committee was formed through Mrs. Maria P., who found out about the program and invited her neighbors to participate in it. Her neighbors and friends joined as there was great acceptance because of the values that the program espouses and promotes. This is a solid committee as after confronting many difficulties during these cycles they overcame conflicts through communication. Costa Alegre Poty is a very solid committee with women committed to their work. Each member has a specific commercial activity that she carries out with the goal of raising money to support her family. These activities are: 1 María P. Store 2 Fidencia Ruíz Vegetable Sales 3 Mirna A. Store 4 Mariza A. Store 5 Lucia S. Milk Sales 6 Damacia B. Store 7 Anuncia M. Charcoal Sales 8 Idalina López Vegetable Sales 9 Ana C. Store 10 Alicia A. Cheese Sales 11 Laura S. Milk Sales 12 Sebastiana G. Dental Technican 13 Ana M. Sale of Sweet Bread 14 Edith O. Lingerie Sales 15 Maria C. Cigarette Sales Each one receives a loan averaging Gs. 500.000, which they invest in the purchase of milk, sugar, flour, seeds, charcoal, lingerie, tobacco, toothpaste, false teeth, cassava, soft drinks, etc.

Translated from Spanish by Aimee Sostowski, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of milk, sugar, flour, seeds, charcoal, lingerie, tabacco, toothpaste, false teeth, cassava, soft drinks, etc.

loans.name: Irshad Mustafa Group

texts.en:
My name is Irshad and I am a 38 year old married lady.  I have resided in a city named Vehari, Pakistan for the past 20 years.  I am a widow.  My husband died when my son was just 5 years old.  My son was so attached to his father.  He couldn’t pay attention to his education.  Now, he is 17 years old.  

My brother in law lives with us and provides us financial support.  He is a driver and drives an auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle).  My son will help him in future by driving this vehicle.  I stay at home and spend my time sewing clothes that I collect from my neighbors.  

I am applying for a loan to buy another auto-rickshaw for my brother in law so that he can train my son, and he will be able to start driving in future. 

I am a group leader of a few more women in my locality.  Kalsoom Baji wants a loan to buy a donkey cart for loading different items.  Ulfat Baji wants a loan to buy birds (pigeons) for her bird selling business.  Ramzana Baji wants a loan to buy scrap for her scrap business.  Shamim Baji wants a loan to repair a vehicle (Shahzore). 

This is a group loan.  The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business.  The members mutually guarantee one another's loans.  If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy an auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle)

loans.name: Saleeman Allah Yar Muhammad Group

texts.en:
My name is Saleeman and I am 46 years old and have been married since I was 16. I belong to a city named Vehari, Pakistan. My husband's name is A. Y. M., and he works in a factory. I have one son, Talib. He drives a rented auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle). I am a housewife and I make embroidered dresses to earn money. It takes 10 days to complete a heavily embroidered dress which I sell in the market for $3. I am requesting a loan to buy auto-rickshaw for my son so he doesn't have to pay for renting one and can increase his income. 

There are 3 other members in my loan group: Zahooran baji requests a loan to buy inventory for her grocery shop. Ramzana baji requests a loan to buy material (lentils, cooking oil and spices) for her food business. Shamshad baji requests a loan to repair her auto-rickshaw.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy an auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle)

loans.name: Irshad Gallu Group

texts.en:
My name is Irshad and I am a 43-year-old married lady. I live in Vehari, Pakistan. I own a two-room brick house in which I have lived with my family for the past 30 years. My husband's name is G. and he works as a delivery man. He specifically delivers fruits and vegetables from one place to another. I am a mother of one son whose name is Ramzan. He is a driver by profession and drives an auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle). 

I have an embroidery business. I make embroidered dresses on order and earn income. I invested some of my income in a committee, and have decided to marry off my son when I receive the committee amount. I successfully repaid my first loan which I took from Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan). Now I am applying for a loan ($500) to repair my son's auto-rickshaw.

I have some more members in my group. Kosar Baji wants a loan to buy an auto-rickshaw. Saima Baji wants a loan to buy scrap for her scrap business. Naseem Baji wants a loan to buy tea and sugar for her tea stall. 

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To repair an auto-rickshaw, purchase another rickshaw, scraps, and goods for a tea stall

loans.name: Kishwar M. Aslam Group

texts.en:
I am Kishwar and I belong to a city named Vehari, Pakistan.  I have been living in this city for the past 40 years.  I am an uneducated lady, but I know how to embroider dresses and how to sew clothes.  It’s a high demand profession in Pakistan.  

I am a married woman and my husband's name is M. A..  He has a grocery shop.  He has been running this shop for the past 40 years.  I have three kids: two sons and one daughter.  All of my children are enrolled in a local school and are getting an education. 

I have successfully repaid my first loan from Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan).  Now I am applying for my second loan to diversify my husband’s grocery shop. 

I am a group leader of a few more members in my locality.  Razia Parveen Baji wants a loan to buy scrap for her scrap business. Shazia Baji wants a loan to repair her auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle).  Irfana Baji and Sumera Baji each want a loan to buy groceries for their grocery shops.  Zareena Mai Baji wants a loan to buy cold drinks for her cold drink corner. 

This is a group loan.  The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business.  The members mutually guarantee one another's loans.  If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy groceries for her grocery shop

They do different types of work independently in order to maintain their homes such as: 1 Sara Florentin Dressmaker 2 Eliodora S. Street vendor 3 Maria S. Food sales 4 Perla V. loans.use: Items purchased include: noodles, sugar, rice, flour, meat, fruit, tapioca, giblets, fabric, jeans, t-shirts, carbonated soft drinks, and charcoal.

loans.name: Mairaj Bibi Ashraf Group

texts.en:
I am 39 years old lady and my name is Mairaj Bibi.  I reside in a city, which famous for its shrine places, named Pakpattan, Pakistan.  I have been a part of this city for the past 15 years.  

My husband's name is Mr. A., and he makes utensils from mud and sells them in handicrafts shops.  I have seven kids: three sons and four daughters.  My elder son works in a cold drink factory.  The other two are enrolled in a local school and are getting an education.  My daughters are also getting education. 

I have a stripe making business. (Stripes are used by women, specifically to tie their hair).  I have been making these stripes for the past 6 years.  

I successfully repaid my 1st loan from Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan).  Now I am applying again for a loan to buy thread for making stripes to sell.

I am a group leader of a few more members of my locality.  Naseem Baji wants a loan to buy thread and beads for making embroidered dresses.  Shahida Bukhari Baji wants a loan to buy motorbike spare parts to resell.  Kaneez Fatima Baji wants a loan to change the body of an auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle).  Ashran Baji wants a loan to buy furniture (chairs and tables) for her tuition.  Safia Baji wants a loan to buy clothes to resell.

This is a group loan.  The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business.  The members mutually guarantee one another's loans.  If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy material for her stripe-making business

loans.name: Leoncio

texts.es:
El señor Leoncio Álvarez es de la ciudad de San Estanislao tiene 57 años de edad, se dedica a la producción de carbón vegetal, tiene 2 hornos donde produce 1000 kilos de carbón semanalmente. Ya posee una gran clientela formada y por ende tiene buenos ingresos, esto es gracias a los buenos tratos con los clientes, y también buena calidad de su producto.
Invertirá este crédito en la construcción de otro horno ya que tiene muchos pedido, para entregar especialmente en estas fechas de Navidad y Año Nuevo.
Desea a todas las personas del mundo que através de Kiva invierten en microempresarios como él, una Feliz Navidad y un Próspero Año Nuevo desde su país.
texts.en:
Mr. Leoncio Álvarez is from the city of San Estanislao. He is 57 years old and devotes himself to making charcoal. He has two ovens where he produces 1000 kilograms (2205 lbs) of charcoal per week. He has a large customer base already built up, so he has a good income, thanks to his fair dealings with the customers as well as the high quality of his product.

He will invest this credit in the construction of another oven, since he has a lot of orders to fulfill, particularly for the upcoming Christmas and New Year holidays. He wishes everyone in the world who uses Kiva to invest in small businesses like his a Merry Christmas and a Happy New Year from his country.

Translated from Spanish by Shannon Skoglund, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Build another brick oven

loans.name: Zakia Hakim Shah Group

texts.en:
I am a 46 year old lady and my name is Zakia Bibi.  I reside in a city named Pakpattan, Pakistan, which is famous for its shrine places.  I have been a part of this city for the past 10 years.  

My husband's name is H. S., and he works in a grindstone mill where he grinds wheat & rice.  He earns 1500 rupees per month.  I have four kids: one son and three daughters.  My son works in a factory.  My daughters are all enrolled in a local school to get an education. 

I became seamstress because my husband’s income is very low.  My husband works day and night but his struggle is still not rewarded.  So, my husband has decided to change his work and has chosen the profession of driver.  

Therefore, I am requesting a loan to buy an auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle) for my husband so that he can pay his duties efficiently and with strong determination. 

I am a group leader of a few more members of my locality.  Zareena Baji wants a loan to buy material (lentils, cooking oil and spices) for her food business.  Sheema Baji and Haleema Baji each want a loan to buy thread and beads for their decorative embroidery businesses.  Mairaj Baji wants a loan to buy artificial flowers to resell. 

This is a group loan.  The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business.  The members mutually guarantee one another's loans.  If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy an auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle)

loans.name: Aziz Fatima Liaqat Ali Group

texts.en:
I am Aziz Fatima and I am 37-years old, married, and live in Pakpattan, Pakistan which is famous for its shrine. named Pakpattan, Pakistan. I completed my education till 5th standard, but couldn’t study further due to the poor financial condition of my household. I have 7children, 3 sons and 4 daughters. All of my children are getting an education in a local school in my neighborhood. My husband, L. A., has been in the clothes-selling business for 4 years. He needs to replenish his inventory so he can earn more income. I have repaid my two loans from Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan). Now I am requesting a loan to buy clothes for my husband’s business. 

I am a group leader with 5 other members in my group: Irshad baji requests a loan to buy a sewing machine for her sewing business. Parveen baji requests a loan to buy plastic utensils to resell. Azra baji requests a loan to buy an instrument (keyboard) for her band. Parveen akhtar baji requests a loan to buy sugar to resell. 

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy clothes to resell

loans.name: Fatima Group

texts.en:
I am Fatima and I am 42-years old, a widow, and I reside in a city which famous for its shrines, Pakpattan, Pakistan. My husband left me with four sons. I completely lost my senses when I became widow just after 12 years of marriage. I worked very hard to survive with my children. First I sewed clothes for my neighbors. Than I started making stripes (women use these to tie their hair) and selling them in markets. I collected a good number of customers who love to use my stripes. I found a good institute where my elder son learned electrician skills. Now he is an electrician. The next oldest works in a sweetmeat shop. The others are getting an education in a local school. My stripe-making business is 15-years old. I have successfully repaid my first loan from Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan). Now I’m requesting a loan to buy thread for business so I can increase production. 

I am a group leader with 4 other members in my group. Zahida baji and Ayesha baji each request a loan to buy an auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle). Nusrat baji requests a loan to buy beams for her shuttering business. Sana baji requests a loan to buy a sewing machine for sewing clothes. 

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy thread for making stripes

loans.name: Azra M. Shafique Group

texts.en:
Azra Baji is a 44 year old married lady who resides in a famous historical place named Yadgar in the city of Lahore, Pakistan.  She owns a two-room brick house and has been living in it with her family for the past 20 years. 

Azra Baji completed her education up until the 8th standard.  She couldn’t study further due to the low financial circumstances of her house.  Her mother was a seamstress and she delivered her art to Azra because she believes that this is a tool that every woman can use in very crucial circumstances. 

Azra's husband's name is M. S., and he is a plumber by profession.  She has three kids: one son and two daughters.  Her son belongs to a cloth selling business.  Her daughters sell plastic shopping bags in the market and earn a profit.  Azra baji is also involved in her daughters' business.  They make contributions to improve their financial condition. 

Azra Baji successfully repaid her two loans from Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan).  Now she is applying for a loan to buy more clothes to expand her son’s cloth selling business. 

She is a group leader of a few more members of her locality.  Maqsoodan Baji and Zareena Baji each want a loan to buy groceries for their grocery shop.  Parveen Baji wants a loan to buy scrap for her scrap business.  Sheena Baji wants a loan to buy religious books (Islamic) for her book shop. 

This is a group loan.  The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business.  The members mutually guarantee one another's loans.  If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy clothes to resell

loans.name: Akbar Ghulam Muhammad Group

texts.en:
Akbar Baji is a 58 year old married lady who resides in a famous historical place named Yadgar in the city of Lahore, Pakistan.  She has been living in this place for the past 20 years. 

She is an uneducated lady, but she knows the value of education.  She believes that education gives a person success in every walk of life.  She wasn't able to study due to her house’s poor financial conditions.  

Her husband's name is G. M., and he is a property dealer by profession.  He has 6 years of experience in this business.  Her family consists of 13 members.  She has five sons and six daughters.  Her first two sons have government jobs.  The younger to them runs a grocery shop.  The other two are enrolled in a local school in her neighborhood.  Her daughters stay at home and make embroidered dresses.  

Akbar Baji couldn’t give her daughters a good education but she wants to deliver the art of embroidery to them.  Now, her daughters are able to embroider dresses very easily without their mother’s help.  Akbar Baji is pleased to see her daughters accomplish this art.  She got her daughters involved in this work because inflation is increasing rapidly and it is difficult for a person to manage all of the household expenses.  She and her daughters share part of the income with their family members. 

Akbar Baji successfully repaid her three loans from Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan).  Now she is applying for a loan to buy groceries to expand her son’s grocery shop. 

She is a group leader of a few more members of her locality.  Rukhsana Baji wants a loan to buy utensils to resell.  Razia Baji wants a loan to buy electric switches to resell.  Asia Baji wants a loan to buy iron to resell.  Safia Baji wants a loan to buy materials (beads and colored thread) to make embroidery on shoes.

This is a group loan.  The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business.  The members mutually guarantee one another's loans.  If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy groceries for a grocery shop

loans.name: Tonnere Group

texts.en:
André B. operates a drugstore in Bumbu (an Eastern suburban area of Kinshasa). He is 61 years old, and a father of six children who are between the ages of 2 and 30. Three of them are already married, and two are students and live with him.

He began his business in 2004, after the company where he used to work closed due to political and economic instability. He started his business with a capital of $100. With hard work and good management, and by providing good customer service, Andre’s business has prospered and has permanent customers to keep it up. André’s wife is a nurse and has been helping him by promoting the business. As a nurse, she has been helping André make the best choices about purchasing appropriate drugs in the area. She works with him in developing the drugstore. They both like their business and they also like talking to their customers about their health. André has been in one of Hope’s loan groups since last July. He is planning to expand his business with the new loan, by opening another drugstore.

loans.use: To expand the business by opening another drugstore

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Rani Sharif Group

texts.en:
Rani baji is a 43 year old lady who resides in a famous historical place called Yadgar in Pakistan. She owns a two room brick house in this place, where she has been living with her family for the past 3 years. Rani baji is a widow. Her husband died of a heart attack. His sudden death made her mentally unstable, but she recovered when she saw that her children were sad and depressed. She toughened herself for the sake of her children. She started sewing clothes by taking orders from her neighbors. One of her neighbors helped her out by giving her a contact at a garment factory. The factory owner gave her number of clothes to stitch. She completed the order and earned an income.

With this income, she started a business of making steel wire. She handed over this business to her sons. Now they are independently handling this business and earning income. Her first two daughters work in a cold drink factory and her younger daughter reads in 4th standard. Rani baji successfully repaid her two loans from Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan). Now she is applying for a loan to buy some more tools to expand her sons' steel wire business. 

She is a group leader of a few more members of her locality. Suraiya baji and Nasreen baji each want a loan to buy groceries for their grocery shop. Naseem baji wants a loan to buy iron to resell. Bilquis baji wants a loan to buy cigarettes to resell. 

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy tools for making steel wire

loans.name: Nasreen Akhtar M. Ramzan Group

texts.en:
Nasreen akhtar baji is a 36 year old married lady who lives in a famous historical place named Yadgar in the city Lahore, Pakistan. She has lived in this place for the past 5 years. She completed her education to 8th standard but couldn’t study further. Her mother was a midwife, and now she works in the same profession. Her husband's name is M. R., and he has run a grocery shop in the community for the past 10 years. People are used to coming to him to buying groceries, and he has a good reputation in this business.

Nasreen baji is a mother of two kids: one son and one daughter. Her son reads in 3rd standard and her daughter reads in 5th standard. Nasreen baji successfully repaid her first loan from Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan). Now she is applying for a loan again to buy groceries to diversify her husband’s grocery shop into a grocery store. 

She is a group leader of a few more members of her locality. Shamshad baji wants a loan to change the body of her auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle). Nasreen baji wants a loan to buy religious (Islamic) books for her bookshop. Shabnam baji wants a loan for her holy book (Quran-e-Pak) selling business. Farzana baji wants a loan to buy leather and nails for her shoe making business. 

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy groceries for grocery shop

loans.name: Shakeela Nazeer Ahmad Group

texts.en:
Shakeela baji is 39 years old and lives in a famous historical place called Yadgar, in Pakistan. She has lived in this city for the past 15 years. She is an uneducated lady, and she wants to get an education but her dream isn't being fulfilled. Her husband's name is N. A., who sells animal feed. He has been in this business for the past 13 years. She is the mother of five kids: four sons and one daughter. Her elder son helps his father in his business. The next one is a delivery man and delivers items in his donkey cart from one place to another. The last two sons have a plastic shopping bag sales business. Her daughter reads in 7th standard.

Shakeela baji makes plastic shopping bags and her sons go to the market to sell them. She successfully repaid her four loans from Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan). Now she is applying for a loan to buy animal feed to expand her husband’s business.

She is a group leader of a few more member of her locality. Rubina baji wants a loan to buy CD’s to resell. Zubaida baji wants a loan to buy iron to resell. Shamim baji wants a loan to buy utensils to resell. Rizwana baji wants a loan to buy groceries for her grocery shop. 

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy animal feed to sell

loans.name: Sérgio

texts.pt:
Sérgio M. é natural de Maputo e casado maritalmente e pai de 4 filhos com idade entre 16, 13, 8 e 6 anos respectivamente. Para alem dos filhos sustenta um sobrinho e uma irmã que vive com eles.

Sérgio estudou até 6ªclasse e parou por falta de condições financeiras da família. Em 1998 iniciou o negocio de venda de tinteiros qual desenvolve até hoje, compra o produto na africa do sul é dono deste negocio. Compra um tinteiro por 100rands( 250,00mt) e vende por 550,00mt. Desta maneira consegue um rendimento mensal de 6000,00mt.

Sérgio vive numa casa própria e solicita empréstimo na Hluvuku pela terceira vez e segunda no Kiva. Onde os dois primeiros pagou com sucesso e está muito grato pelo apoio do Kiva e dos financiadores.

Sérgio futuramente pretende abrir uma papelaria de forma a vender muito material de escritório de forma fixa já que neste momento vende como ambulante e fornece aos revendi dores.
texts.en:
Sérgio M. is a native of Maputo. He is married and has four children -- 6, 8, 13, and 16 years old. In addition to supporting his children, he takes care of his nephew and sister who live with them. He lives in his own house.

Sérgio studied through sixth grade then stopped because his family could not afford more. In 1998 he started a business selling toner cartridges, which he continues today. He buys the product in South Africa and is the owner of this business. He buys toner for 100 rands (250 Meticais, MZN) and sells it for 500 MZN. In this way he is able to make a monthly salary of 6,000 MZN.

Sérgio is requesting his third loan from Hluvuku (Kiva's Field Partner) and his second with Kiva. He repaid his first two loans successfully, and he is very grateful for the support of Kiva and his investors.

In the future, Sérgio plans to open a stationary store where he can sell many office supplies. It will be a permanent store, whereas currently he is a traveling salesperson and supplies resellers.

Translated from Portuguese by April Newman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy and sell toner

loans.name: Safia M. Rafique Group

texts.en:
My name is Safia and I am a 47 year old married lady. I live in a famous historical place named Yadgar, in the city Lahore, Pakistan. I own a two room brick house in this place. I received an education up to 5th standard but couldn’t study further due to difficult circumstances at home. My husband's name is M. R., who is in the business of food sales. He sells Punjabi food (Daal chawal), and it is famous in the community. I have three kids: one son and two daughters. My son completed his education up to 8th standard but didn't continue his education because he was interested in his father’s food business. My daughters are attending the local school in the community, and both are in 7th standard. My elder daughter wants to be a doctor and my younger daughter wants to be a teacher. I help my husband by preparing food and delivering it to his shop. We both work hard to fulfill our daughters' desires. I have successfully repaid my five loans from Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan). Now I am applying again for a loan to buy ingredients (lentils, rice, cooking oil and spices) to increase the income of my husband. 

I am a group leader of a few more members of my locality. Sharifan baji wants a loan to buy ingredients (lentils, cooking oil and flour) for her food business. Zahida parveen baji wants a loan to buy scrap for her scrap business. Musarat begum baji wants a loan to buy leather and nails for her shoe making business. Zara baji wants a loan to buy wheels of vehicles to resell. 

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy ingredients for food business

loans.name: Razia Waris Masih Sahoutra Group

texts.en:
My name is Razia and I’m 37 years old and a married lady. I reside in a famous historical place named Yadgar of City Lahore, Pakistan. I have been living in this city for the past 20 years. I got my education up until the 8th grade but for more education, I didn’t show any interest. From the beginning I have had an interest in sewing clothes and embroidery. My husband's name is W. M. S. and he has a scrap business. He sells scrap to the community. In particular, he keeps iron in his stock, and people come to sell and buy iron and other iron items from him. 

I have six children: four daughters and two sons. My eldest daughter is in the 9th grade. The one next to her is in the 8th standard. The youngest to her is in the 7th standard, and my youngest daughter is in the 4th standard. My sons are also read in the 4th standard. I and my husband have decided to share the financial burden. I help him by paying the children’s education expenses through sewing clothes, and he bears the house expenses through his income. I successfully repaid my five loans which I took from Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan). Now I am applying for a loan to buy more scrap (iron) to increase the income of my husband. 

I am a group leader of a few more women of my locality. Shahnaz baji wants a loan to buy an auto-rickshaw (a three-wheeled motor vehicle). Mussarat baji wants a loan to buy paint for her paint business. Shahnaz baji and Nasreen baji each want a loan to buy scrap for their scrap businesses. 

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy scrap (iron) for the scrap business

loans.name: Zareena Waris Masih Group

texts.en:
My name is Zareena and my age is 39 years old. I reside in a famous historical place named Yadgar of City Lahore, Pakistan. I own a two-room brick house and have been living in it with my family for the last 20 years. After completing the 10th standard (grade) my parents arranged my marriage with W. M., who belongs to a spare parts selling business. 

My husband is very kind to me, and he allows me to study further. I went to school to learn how to embroider dresses. After completing the course I started doing my own embroidery business. I go to the bazaar to buy the required material for embroidery. After completing it, I go to the cloth market to sell it. This work gives me 3,000 rupees per month. I complete 4 dresses per month. I have four kids: three sons and one daughter. My daughter is in the 10th standard. My eldest son completed his education in the 10th standard and now works with his father. The others are getting educations in a school near to the house. I am applying for a loan to buy spare parts to grow my husband’s spare parts selling business. 

I am a group leader of a few more women of my locality. Sharifan baji wants a loan to buy an auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle). Rozi baji wants a loan to buy iron to resell. Shahnaz baji wants a loan to buy material (cloth, beads and colored thread) for her decorative embroidery business. Irshad baji wants a loan to buy spare parts of vehicles to resell. 

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy vehicle spare parts to resell

loans.name: Ghulam Fatima Ghulam Nabi Group

texts.en:
My name is G. Fatima and my age is 50 years old. I reside in a famous historical place named Yadgar of City Lahore, Pakistan. I have been living with my family for the last 30 years. I completed my education at the 5th standard (grade) and couldn’t study further due to the poor financial condition of my house. I am a widow. My husband left me with five children. I worked very hard and suffered the poor conditions alone. 

I have a decorative embroidery business. I atach the beads to shawls and sell them in cloth markets and earn a profit. I have five kids: two sons and three daughters. My eldest son has a cloth-selling business and my younger son has a decorative embroidery business. My daughters are make embroidered dresses. Embroidery just became our family business. This work gave us a lot. We’re very thankful to God that we became successful in this business and our living standard became better. I have successfully repaid my five loans from Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan). Now I am applying again for a loan to buy material (cloth, beads and colored thread) to grow our family business. 

I am a group leader of a few more women of my locality. Gulzar baji wants a loan to buy material (cloth, beads and colored thread) for her decorative embroidery business. Parveen baji wants a loan to buy (sugar and cooking oil) for her sweetmeat-selling business. Shahnaz baji wants a loan to buy leather and nails for her shoemaking business. Chanda baji wants a loan to buy utensils to resell.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy materials for her embroidery business

loans.name: Comfort

texts.en: Comfort K. is 70 years old. She is a widowed mother of four children. The last of her children is still dependent on her. Comfort lives with her child and some other family dependents in Obuasi in the Ashanti Region. She produces palm kernel oil and supplies it to the people in her community. Palm kernel oil is produced from the seeds of palm nuts. It is used as a vegetable oil. It is also used to prepare local soap. She buys the palm kernel from the palm oil producers in her community. Comfort has been in business for five years. She wants a loan to buy palm kernel in bulk so she can produce on large scale. Comfort belongs to the All Nation Trust Bank group where the members guarantee for one another as collateral so as to access the loan.

loans.use: To buy palm kernel oil to resell

loans.name: Akua

texts.en: Akua K. is 54 years old. She has lost her husband long ago. Three of her four children have completed school and are now independent. The last born is in senior high school. Akua has provided for her family ever since she lost her husband. She trades in secondhand textile materials. She deals mainly in bedspreads. She buys the textiles in bales from Kumasi, a nearby city, and sells in the local market. She has managed this business for nine years. She desires to buy textiles in bales so that she can trek to markets in nearby towns. Akua belongs to the All Nation Trust Bank group. The members in the group guarantee for one another as collateral so as to access the loan.

loans.use: To buy secondhand textiles in bales for resell

loans.name: Nusrat Faryad Hussain Group

texts.en:
My name is Nusrat and I am a 28-year-old married lady. I reside in a famous historical city named Yadgar of City Lahore, Pakistan. I own a two-room brick house and have been living in it with my family for the last 10 years. I studied until the fifth grade. My husband's name is F. H., and he is a driver by profession and drives a horse cart. He uses this cart to pick up and drop off the people for a fare. I have four kids: three daughters and one son. All of my children are getting an education in a local school near to the community. I sew clothes for my neighbors and earn a profit. I share my income with my husband to help him relax in some way. I am applying for a loan to buy a horse cart because the old ones became rough. 

I am a group leader of a few more women of my locality. Nusrat baji wants a loan to buy vehicle spare parts to resell. Bushra baji and Sajida baji each want a loan to buy ingredients (lentils, flour and cooking oil) for their food businesses. 

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy a horse cart

loans.name: Akosua

texts.en: Akosua S. is a 52-year-old married woman with five children. The last of Akosua’s children is still in the elementary school. The older ones have all completed school and are running their own businesses. Akosua lives with her husband, child and a dependent in the town of Obuasi in the Ashanti Region of Ghana. Akosua produces palm oil, a business that is commonly practiced by most of the women in the Obuasi municipality. She buys the palm nuts, which she uses to prepare the oil, from the farmers in her community. Customers come to buy oil in gallons. Akosua wants a loan so she can procure palm fruits in bulk to be able to produce oil on large scale. Akosua belongs to the All Nation Trust Bank group. The members in the group guarantee for one another as collateral so as to access the loan.

loans.use: To buy palm fruits in bulk

loans.name: Exito Group

texts.es: El grupo "Éxito" esta representado por la señora Dony Mery quien reside en el mismo barrio que sus compañeras de grupo es de ahí que se tienen la confianza como para participar de un grupo juntas por la responsabilidad que demuestran todas en el trabajo. En su mayoría los socios (as) se dedican al comercio de diferentes productos como la ropa, comida, a la elaboración de prendas de vestir y al transporte público. Dentro del rubro del comercio existe mucha competencia en especial dentro de la oferta y la demanda ya que si uno no posee productos de calidad para ofrecer al publico no tiene competitividad, y por ende los ingresos declinan, es por eso que requieren el crédito para incrementar sus insumos y mejorar la calidad de sus productos así como realizar algunas mejoras en sus puestos de trabajo para otorgar una buena imagen al cliente exigente. Por lo que han demostrado los socios (as) tiene experiencia en grupos solidarios y una gran responsabilidad para con sus compromisos por lo que la Fundación Agrocapital les da la oportunidad de obtener un financiamiento para lograr sus metas y mejor su calidad de vida.
texts.en:
The "Success" group is represented by Dony Mery who lives in the same neighborhood as her group partners. It's because they all live in the same neighborhood that they have the confidence to participate together in a group united by the responsibility that each member demonstrates toward her work. The majority of the partners work selling different types of products, such as clothing, food, handmade pieces of clothing and public transportation.Within the commercial sector there exists a lot of competition, particularly in supply and demand, since if you do not have quality products to offer the public, you are not competitive, and your earnings decline. It's for this reason that the partners of this group require a loan in order to increase the quality of their products, by making improvements in their work spaces, for example, in order to present a better image to demanding clientele. The partners of this group have demonstrated that they have experience in supportive groups and a great sense of responsibility to their commitments. Recognizing that, the Fundación Agrocapital is giving them the opportunity to obtain financing to achieve their goals and improve their quality of life.

Translated from Spanish by Erin Corcoran, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Operating capital

loans.name: Christiana

texts.en: Christiana G. is 49 years old. She is married and has three children. Two of her children have completed high school. The last child is currently in the basic (elementary) school. She lives together with her family in a rented apartment in Obuasi. Christiana works to support her husband who also provides for the family. She is a food vendor.
