She cooks rice and stew and sells on the main street in front of her house. She has run this business for two years. Christiana says she buys the uncooked rice in cups from retailers in her community. This, she says, is not cost-effective. For that reason, Christiana wants a loan so she can buy bags of rice and other ingredients such as oil, etc., in bulk to cut down costs. Christiana belongs to a Trust Bank group called “Adom Bi Apue”, which when translated simply means "a grace has dawned." The members in the group guarantee for one another as collateral so as to access the loan.

loans.use: To buy bags of rice and vegetables in bulk

loans.name: Fozia Hafiz Tahir Group

texts.en:
My name is Fozia and I am 25 years old and a married lady. I reside in a city named Pakpattan, Pakistan. Pakpattan city is famous for its shrines. Many people come to visit the city of shrines. I feel lucky that I got a blessing from God to live in this city. I completed my education until the 5th standard (grade). I have no kids. My husband's name is H. T., and he is a wholesaler. He sells wheat and rice in food markets. He has 25 years experience in this business. I help my husband in filling the wheat and rice sacks. I am applying for a loan to buy more wheat and rice to resell. 

I am a group leader of a few more members of my locality. Nasreen baji wants a loan to buy washing powder (soap) to resell. Rashda baji wants a loan to buy wheat to resell. Hanifan baji wants a loan to buy seasonal fruits for her fruit-selling business. Ghulam Fatima baji wants a loan to buy a sewing machine for her sewing business. 

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy wheat and rice to resell

loans.name: Justice

texts.en: Justice A. is 45 years old. He is married and has five children. All his children are still schooling in Obuasi, where they stay. Justice runs two different types of business simultaneously in his community. He trades in cocoa beans and at the same time owns a bicycle shop. He buys the cocoa beans directly from the farmers in the surrounding villages and sells to the cocoa-marketing companies at a premium. Justice has a small kiosk at the market square where he sells spare bicycle parts. Justice says because of his limited working capital, he is unable to procure most of the parts the people need. He wants to use the loan to procure more of the spare parts to meet the demands of his customers. Justice belongs to a Trust Bank group called “Kingdom.” The members in the group guarantee for one another as collateral so as to access the loan.

loans.use: To buy bicycle spare parts and bags of cocoa beans.

loans.name: Antonia

texts.en:
Antonia is a member of the Glorioso Village Bank, one of FINCA Peru’s oldest village banks. Antonia is 42 years old and married with six children. Antonia buys sheep and pigs from the countryside and resells them in one of Ayacucho’s markets, mainly to distributors who then sell the animals to local restaurants. She has had this business for two and a half years now. She works every day of the week, and sells about 120 animals each week. 

Antonia is requesting a loan of 1050 soles, which she will use to buy ten sheep. Her goal for the future is to build her own home using the money from her FINCA savings account.

loans.use: Buy ten sheep

loans.name: Hanifan M.ramzan Group

texts.en:
My name is Hanifan and I have resided in a city named Pakpattan, Pakistan. Pakpattan city is famous for its shrines. Many people visit the city of shrines. I feel lucky that I got a blessing from God to live in this city. I am a 56-year-old married lady. I am not an educated woman but I know responsibilities. I pay my duties as a wife and as a mother effectively. My husband's name is M., and he is a driver by profession and drives an auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle). He has 5 years experience in this profession. I have three kids: two sons and one daughter. My eldest son works as a laundry man and my younger son works as a ticket checker in a local bus. My daughters read in the 8th standard (grade). I help my eldest son in his clothes-washing business. I am applying for a loan to repair my husband’s auto-rickshaw so that he able to continue his work again and earn a profit. 
 
I am a group leader of a few more members in my locality. Sakina baji wants a loan to buy buffalo for her milk-selling business. Shamim baji wants a loan to buy furniture (chairs) for her barber saloon. Naseem baji and Hafizan baji each want a loan to buy cloth for their cloth-selling businesses.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To repair an auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle)

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en: Margaret M. is a 35-year-old man. He is married and has five children. The first born, a son, is independent, while two are in the college currently. The last two are also in junior high school. Margaret works to support her husband financially. She is a fishmonger. She buys fresh fish from cold stores in the nearby cities and smokes them. She distributes to food vendors in her community and also sells in the market square. She says she has been in business for twelve years. Margaret wants a loan to procure fresh fish in bulk so that she can distribute to more customers. Margaret belongs to a Trust Bank group called “Kingdom.” The members in the group guarantee for one another as collateral so as to access the loan.

loans.use: To buy fresh fish in bulk

loans.name: Rigoberta

texts.en:
Rigoberta is a member of the Glorioso Village Bank, one of FINCA Peru’s oldest village banks. She is a cheerful, lively woman who likes to joke around and always brings a smile to the face of those around her. She is 36-year-old and married with two children. Rigoberta has a market stand where she sells dry goods (like flour, sugar, rice and pasta), a business she has had for the past three years. She works alone from 5 am to 2 pm each day. Her husband works as a taxi driver.

Rigoberta is requesting a loan of 900 soles to buy rice, sugar and oil. Her goal for the future is to build her own home.

loans.use: Buy rice, sugar and oil

loans.name: Juan

texts.en:
Juan is a member of the Glorioso Village Bank, one of FINCA Peru’s oldest village banks. Juan is 66 years old and is married with seven children, all of whom are now working professionals. Juan runs a liquor store, where he works every day selling beer, soda, caña (a liquor maD. from sugarcane) and pure alcohol. He has had this business for more than 40 years now. 

Juan plans to use his loan of 3,000 soles (US$1,000) to buy a variety of drinks to restock his store. 

Juan’s goal for the future is to buy some land to build a house on. He already has two houses, but he wants to build another one so that his children can live there and will always remember him.

loans.use: Buy drinks to restock his liquor store

loans.name: Anwari Begum Group

texts.en:
I am Anwari begum and I reside in a city named Pakpattan, Pakistan. Pakpattan city is famous for its shrines. Many people come to visit the city of shrines. I feel I got a blessing from God to live in this city. I am a 58-year-old widow. My husband left me alone with three children. I have spent 15 years as a widow. I worked hard to give my children a good future. I sew clothes day and night and earn income. I invest some of my income in a committee. Through that amount I opened a grocery shop for my son. Now his business is going well. My eldest daughter reads in the 10th standard (grade) and my younger daughter reads in the 9th standard. My children feel proud of me, and I thank God that he helped me with all the problems. I am applying for a loan to diversify my son’s grocery shop by buying more types of groceries. 

I am a group leader of a few more members in the locality. Anwar baji and Shakooran baji each want a loan to buy chairs for their barbershops. Manzooran baji and Nasreen baji each want a loan to buy groceries for their grocery shops. 

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy groceries for my grocery shop

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en: Elizabeth N. is 38 years old. She is married and has four children who are all currently in school. She lives with her family in Obuasi in the Ashanti Region of Ghana. Elizabeth has been selling infant layettes such as baby’s cots, Pampers, etc., and other textile materials for eight years. She procures her goods from big shops in the city at wholesale prices. She sells in the market square in her community and also hawks to houses. Elizabeth wants a loan to procure the goods in bulk so that she can trek to nearby markets. Elizabeth belongs to a Trust Bank group called “Kingdom.” The members in the group guarantee for one another as collateral so as to access the loan. She said she would be grateful for your assistance.

loans.use: To procure infant layettes in bulk such as Pampers, diapers, feeding bottles, etc.

loans.name: Jamila Bakhtayar Ahmad Group

texts.en:
I am Jamila and I am a 24-year-old married lady. I reside in a city named Pakpattan, Pakistan. Pakpattan city is famous for its shrine. Many people come to visit the city of shrines. I feel I got a blessing from God to live in this city.  I completed my education in the 8th standard (grade). I own a two-room brick house in which I have lived with my family for the past 9 years. I have three more members in my family there. I am a mother of two kids: one son and one daughter. Both of my children are in kindergarten. My husband is a fruit seller with experience of 3 years. My brother-in-law also lives with us. He has a clothing business with experience of 2 years. He buys clothing from a famous city Multan and sells in big markets of Pakpattan. I am applying for a loan to expand my brother-in-law’s clothing business. 

I am a group leader of a few more members of my locality. Azra parveen baji wants a loan to buy wood for her furniture-making business. Suraiya baji and Hafizan baji each want a loan to buy wheat to resell. Rukhsana baji wants a loan to buy a sewing machine for her sewing business. Asia parveen baji wants a loan to buy an auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle). 

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy clothes for clothing-selling business

loans.name: Reynalda Fausta

texts.en:
Reynalda is a member of the Imperio (“Empire”) Village Bank. She is 47 years old and lives with her common-law husband and their six children. Their youngest child is six years old, while their older children are adults. Reynalda is a seamstress; she sews custom clothing in her home, mostly for women. She has had this business for many years, and she works alone. Reynalda also sells meals on Sundays from her home. 

Reynalda is requesting a loan of 1050 soles to buy fabric and other materials for sewing clothing. Her goal for the future is to open her own restaurant.

loans.use: Buy fabric and other materials for sewing clothes

loans.name: Teresa

texts.en:
Teresa is a member of the Imperio (“Empire”) Village Bank. She is a 40-year-old single mother and has two children. She buys grains in regional markets, then brings them to the city of Ayacucho and grinds them into flour to sell. She works alone seven days a week, from 4 a.m. to 3 p.m. 

Teresa is requesting a loan of 600 soles to buy more grains (broad beans, corn, wheat, and barley) in the countryside. Her goal for the future is to open her own restaurant to sell soups and mondongo (tripe stew).

loans.use: Buy broad beans, corn, wheat and barley

loans.name: Munawar Irshad Ahmad Group

texts.en:
I am Munawar and I am 40-years old, married, and live in Pakpattan, Pakistan, a city famous for its shrines. I feel  lucky that I got a blessing from God to live be a part of this city. My husband, I. A., works in a factory. I have five children: 4 daughters and 1 son. All of my children are enrolled in a local school and getting an education. My husband pays the household expenses and I pay for the education of my children with my clothes-selling business, a business I've had for over 2 years. I am requesting a loan to buy more clothes to expand my business. 

I am a group leader with 4 others in my group: Bushra baji requests a loan to buy a hair dressing machine for her parlor. Nasreen baji requests a loan to buy wheat to resell. Zubaida baji requests a loan to buy meat to resell. Zareena baji requests a loan to buy a donkey cart for loading. 

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy clothes to resell

loans.name: Margarita

texts.en:
Margarita is a member of the Muchuy Warakaq Village Bank. She is 41 years old and lives with her partner and their two children. Margarita sells small animals, like guinea pigs, hens, ducks and turkeys. Farmers bring her the animals, and she sells them from her stand in the April 12th Market in the city of Ayacucho. She works there alone, seven days per week, from 8 am to 6 pm. She sells to the general public and also has regular customers. Margarita has 20 years of experience in this business. She also has a small dry goods store in her home.

Margarita is requesting a loan of 1050 soles to buy turkeys to sell for the holiday season. Each turkey costs 80-120 soles, depending on its size, so she will be able to buy 8-12 turkeys. Margarita dreams of stocking up her dry goods store and working exclusively from home.

loans.use: To buy turkeys to sell for the holiday season.

loans.name: Edith Norma

texts.en:
Edith is a member of the Muchuy Warakaq Village Bank. She is 59 years old and married with four children, two of whom still live at home. Edith and her husband run a hardware store from their home, which they have had for the past 18 years. Edith works each day from 6:30 am to 8:30 pm.

Edith is requesting a loan of 1200 soles to buy construction materials, mostly normal and fine-grain sand. Her goal for the future is to finish construction on her hardware store, which is currently missing part of the roof.

loans.use: To buy construction materials (different grades of sand).

loans.name: Marylin Rocio

texts.en:
Marylin is a member of the Muchuy Warakaq Village Bank. She is 38 years old and lives with her partner and their three children. Marilyn works for an insurance company selling different kinds of insurance policies. She is paid a 3% commission on each policy she sells, but she has to put down a deposit on the policies before she can sell them. The deposit is 10,000 soles (about $3,250) for every 30 certificates, or about $108 per certificate.

Marylin is requesting a loan of 2100 soles to put towards down payment on her insurance policies. Her dream for the future is to open her own insurance agency.

loans.use: To pay the deposit on insurance policies to sell.

loans.name: Blanca Edith

texts.en:
Edith is a member of the Muchuy Warakaq Village Bank. She is 38 years old and married with three children. Edith and her husband own a business selling construction materials like sand and renting out heavy machinery. The couple has been running this business since 1997, and currently has five employees.

Edith is requesting a loan of 1200 soles to buy fuel for the machinery. She says 1200 soles worth of fuel will last for one to two days, and she plans to take out loans with other financial institutions to pay for the rest of the fuel she needs.

Edith’s goal for the future is to continue to expand her business and to buy more heavy machinery.

loans.use: To pay for the fuel for heavy machinery.

loans.name: Guapuru Group

texts.es: EL GRUPO "GUAPURÚ" ESTA REPRESENTADO POR LA SEÑORA ANA. DENTRO DEL CUAL EXISTE UN PARENTESCO ENTRE ERICKA Y MIREYA ELLAS SON HERMANAS, PERO CADA UNA TIENE  INDEPENDENCIA ECONÓMICA Y SON TOTALMENTE INDEPENDIENTES. EN SU MAYORÍA LOS SOCIOS (AS) SE DEDICAN AL COMERCIO D. PRODUCTOS COMO CONFITES, PINTURA , PAN, ROPA, DOMÉSTICOS Y A LA PINTURA D. VIVIENDAS. DENTRO DEL MERCADO SIEMPRE EXISTE LA COMPETENCIA PERO LA EXPERIENCIA D. LAS SOCIAS PREDOMINA PARA CONTINUAR SIN PROBLEMAS. EL DESTINO DEL CRÉDITO ES PARA INCREMENTAR SUS PRODUCTOS Y MATERIALES A LA VENTA Y AL INCREMENTO D. INSUMOS PARA LA ELABORACIÓN D. PAN. DENTRO DEL GRUPO EXISTEN SOCIAS D. LAS CUALES NUNCA TRABAJARON CON GRUPOS SOLIDARIOS PERO TIENEN MUCHA RESPONSABILIDAD Y COMPROMISO CON SUS COMPAÑERAS D. GRUPO PARA SALIR ADELANTE TODOS JUNTOS.
texts.en:
Ana represents the 'Guaparú' group. Two of the group members, Ericka and Mireya are related (sisters), but each of them is economically independent and they are completely independent from each other. For the most part, the members sell products such as candy, paint, bread, clothing, and household supplies and offer house painting. In the marketplace there is always competition, but these members have no problem succeeding because of their experience. This loan will be used to increase the products and materials they have for sale, and to get more ingredients for making bread. Some members of the group have not worked with village banking groups before, but they are very responsible and committed to their partners so that everyone can come out ahead.

Translated from Spanish by Kelly Wester, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Operating capital

loans.name: Norma Noemi

texts.en:
Norma is a member of the Amaqella Village Bank. Amaqella means “Don’t be lazy” in Quechua. Norma is 46 years old and is married with three children. Norma sells clothing and pajamas, mostly for women and children. She started her business 15 years ago, when she first began working with FINCA Peru. She sells door-to-door and also takes special orders from her clients.

Norma is requesting a loan of 2100 soles to buy yellow clothing for the New Year’s season (in Peru, it is considered good luck to ring in the New Year wearing yellow clothing or underwear). Her goal for the future is to obtain more investment capital so that she can open her own boutique to sell trendy clothes.

loans.use: To buy yellow clothing to sell for New Year's.

loans.name: Kalsoom M.akram Group

texts.en:
My name is Kalsoom and I’m a 28 year-old married lady. I reside in a city named Pakpattan, Pakistan. Pakpattan city is famous for its shrine places. Most of the people come to visit the city of shrine places. I feel myself lucky that I got a blessing from God to live and be a part of this city. I’m an uneducated lady but I have a belief that knowledge gives a person respect in people and it rewards you in every walk of life. My husband's name is M. and he runs a PCO (Public call office). People used to come to his office for making calls. He charges fee for calls. I have three kids: two sons and one daughter. All of my kids are getting educated in a local school near the house. I am a seamstress and do this work for earning profit. As we all know, inflation is increasing rapidly and it's difficult for a single person to serve his family. I help my husband to meet the financial expenses. I have successfully repaid my first loan from Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan). Now I am applying for a loan to buy a new telephone set for my husband’s PCO. 
I am a group leader of a few more members of my locality. Tahmina baji wants a loan to buy decorative lights for her decoration work. Maryam baji wants a loan to buy a donkey cart for loading. Kalsoom baji wants a loan to buy animals (goats and sheep) to resell. Zareena ashraf baji wants a loan to buy a sewing machine for sewing clothes. 

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy a new telephone set for PCO (Public call office)

loans.name: Juana

texts.en:
Juana is a member of the Amaqella Village Bank; “Amaqella” means “Don’t be lazy” in Quechua. She is 48 years old and married with six children. Juana and her husband sell construction materials, mainly bricks and sand. They inherited the brick-selling business from Juana’s parents, and they started selling sand about 20 years ago. Juana and her husband take the sand from a nearby river and buy the bricks directly from the manufacturers. They sell both sand and bricks from their car, and have many regular customers.

Juana is requesting a loan of 1500 soles to buy fuel for her vehicle and pay her brick-makers. Her goal for the future is to buy a bigger car to haul more construction materials around.

loans.use: Buy fuel for vehicle, pay brick makers

loans.name: Vivian

texts.en:
Vivian O., 35, is married and the mother of two children who attend school. She is a serious-minded businesswoman who works hard to help her husband provide for her family. She owns and operates a grocery shop and sells items like rice, sugar, vegetable oil, bottled water, body and hair creams, skimmed powdered milk, etc. in the marketplace of Obuasi where she lives with her family.

This is a business she has been running almost six years, and she deems this an opportunity to expand her business and wants to use the loan to buy more bags of rice, bags of sugar, cartons of vegetable oil, boxes of body and hair creams etc. to increase her stock of goods available for sale.

Vivian belongs to the community group called ‘Obotantim’ Trust Group. In this group, members guarantee for one another as social collateral to access the loan and peer pressure to repay the loan. Vivian is convinced that the loan will enable her to buy more at a moderate price to reduce her purchase costs. It is also her dream to finance her kids' education to the university level, all things being equal.

loans.use: to buy more bags of rice, bags of sugar, etc. for re-sale

loans.name: Warama

texts.en:
Warama S. is thirty years old. She is married with five children who are currently in school, due to the help of government free compulsory education for every child. However, she is still constrained by inadequate funds to make business progress. She owns and operates a grocery shop and sells items such as rice, sugar, vegetable oil, bottled water, body and hair creams, skimmed powdered milk, etc. She deems it an opportunity to expand her business and wants to use the loan to buy more bags of rice, bags of sugar, cartons of vegetable oil, boxes of body and hair creams, etc. to increase her stock of goods available for sale.

Warama has run this business for three years; she uses the proceeds to cater for her household needs. She travels to Kumasi which is one of the busiest markets to buy her stock of goods. Warama belongs to the community group called Kingdom Trust Group. In this group, members guarantee for one another as social collateral to access the loan and peer pressure to repay the loan.

loans.use: to buy more bags of rice, bags of sugar, etc.  for re-sale

loans.name: Taj Begum Group

texts.en:
"My name is Taj begum and I’m a 43-year-old widow. I reside in a city named Pakpattan, Pakistan. I have been a part of this shrine city for the past 15 years. My husband died and left me with six children: five sons and one daughter. My eldest son has a henna-selling business. Two others are mechanics and run a motor workshop. My younger children are getting education in a local school in the community. After my husband’s death, I started selling milk in milk shops. I get up early in the morning and milk the buffalo. My daughter helps me do the milking and fill milk jars. I am applying for a loan for my eldest son who wants to sell jewelry along with henna.  

"I am the group leader for a few more members from my locality. Jamila baji wants a loan to repair her vehicle of the  "Shahzore" make. Kaniz begum baji wants a loan to repair an auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle). Hanifan baji wants a loan to buy groceries for her grocery shop. Riaz begum baji wants a loan to change the body of her auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle). Naima baji wants a loan to buy fertilizer to re-sell." 

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy jewelry to re-sell

loans.name: Comfort

texts.en:
Comfort G. is forty-five years old and married with four children. Two of her children have completed high school. Comfort is working very hard to help her husband earn enough to send their children to higher levels of academics.

Comfort trades in textiles such as clothes, pants, etc. She has been in business for ten years. She buys from the nearby towns and sells in the community market. Comfort wants a bigger working capital so that she can procure in bulk and trek to nearby villages to sell. She desires to secure a loan to be able to achieve this. Comfort belongs to a Trust Bank group called “Kingdom”. The members in the group guarantee for one another as collateral so as to access the loan. She says she would be grateful for your assistance.

loans.use: To buy textiles in bulk for re-sale

loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
Married with two children, Grace E. is 38 years old. She sells maize and other grains. She travels to Techieman in the Brong Ahafo region of Ghana to buy maize, which she resells at home. She started this grocery three years ago with a small amount of working capital, but through commitment and hard work Grace can now boast of a growing business, for which she gives credit to God. These profits are a wonderful resource for her family.

She would use this loan to stockpile maize so that she can serve her customers throughout the season. Buying now to freeze the price is especially important in the face of inflationary pressures due to the current food crisis in the country. She believes the loan will help her upgrade her business. 

She belongs to a trust group called "Obotantim," meaning rock. In this group, members guarantee each others' loans as social collateral and thus support each other in repaying the loan.

loans.use: To buy maize and beans to restock a grocery shop.

loans.name: Silvia

texts.en:
Silvia is a member of the Bonanza Village Bank.  She is 38 years old and lives with her partner and their three children. Silvia runs a restaurant in a rented space near the Abastos Market in the city of Ayacucho. She works seven days a week, dividing the work with four employees. In the evenings Silvia also sells roasted chicken. Silvia is hoping to move to a larger rental space soon.  

Silvia needs a loan of 1050 soles to buy tables for her restaurant.  Silvia dreams that her children will graduate from college with professional degrees. She also dreams of  a wholesale dry goods stores. 

Translated from Spanish by Cynthia McMurry, Kiva fellow
Silvia es socia del Banco Comunal Bonanza. 
Silvia es conviviente, tiene 38 años y 3 hijos, Silvia tiene un restaurante en un local alquilado que se ubica cerca al mercado de abastos de la ciudad de Ayacucho, actividad que realiza todos los días con la ayuda de 4 ayudantes, además por las noches vende pollos a la brasa, Silvia tiene proyectado alquilar un local mas grande. 
Silvia necesita un préstamo de 1050 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de muebles de mesa. 
Silvia sueña con que sus hijos sean profesionales, tener una tienda de abarrotes al por mayor.

loans.use: To buy tables for a restaurant

loans.name: Graciela

texts.en:
Graciela is a member of the Bonanza Village Bank.  Graciela is 47 years old and married. She has seven children. Graciela lives near the Acocro District, in a community located about an hour away. Graciela runs a store from her home, where she and her son sell dry goods, fruits, and vegetables. Graciela also raises animals and farms.

Graciela is asking for a loan of 1200 soles to buy rice, sugar, and milk to stock her store.  Graciela’s dreams are for her children to graduate from high school and go to college in Ayacucho, and to offer a wider variety of merchandise in her store. 

Translated from Spanish by Cynthia McMurry, Kiva fellow
Graciela es socia del Banco Comunal Bonanza. 
Graciela es casada, tiene 47 años y 7 hijos, Graciela vive en el distrito D. Acocro en una comunidad que se encuentra a 1 hora del distrito, Graciela tiene una tienda en su casa en donD. venD. abarrotes, fruta, verduras, actividad que realiza con la ayuda D. su hijo. Además Graciela se dedica a la crianza D. animales y agricultura. 
Graciela necesita un préstamo D. 1200 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra D. arroz, azúcar, leche. 
Los sueños D. Graciela son que sus hijos culminen sus estudios secundarios y luego estudien la universidad en la ciudad D. Ayacucho, tener una tienda mas surtida.

loans.use: To buy rice, sugar, and milk

loans.name: Khursheed Bibi Mr. Rafiq Group

texts.en:
My name is Khursheed Bibi. I am a fifty-year-old woman. I have lived in the city of Pakpattan, Pakistan, for 15 years. My husband, Mr. R., is a mason. I have three kids: one son and two daughters. My son runs a furniture making business. My elder daughter is in 9th standard and my younger in 8th standard. I run a decorative embroidery business. I embroider dresses and sell them in clothing markets. I charge $3 per dress. I invest my income in my daughters’ education (paying school and tuition fees). I’ve successfully repaid two previous loans from Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan). Now I am applying again for a loan to buy lumber to expand my son’s furniture making business. 

I am the leader of a group of entrepreneurs sharing this loan. Abida Irshad Baji wants a loan to buy jewelry to resell. Qambar Baji wants a loan to buy paint to stock her paint shop. Zareena Baji wants a loan to buy groceries to restock her grocery shop. Safia Baji wants a loan to buy silver from which she manufactures jewelry to sell. 

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy lumber for a furniture making business

loans.name: Ernestina

texts.en:
Ernestina D. is a married woman. She is 42 years old and has five children. Some of her children are in tertiary school, while others are in junior and senior high school. It is her desire to help her husband sponsor all their children to the tertiary level. 

Ernestina has been a baker for over 12 years. She distributes her freshly baked bread to retailers in her community. Ernestina buys her materials including flour, margarine, and sugar, from Kumasi, a nearby city. She wants the loan so that she can buy ingredients in bulk to meet the increasing demand of her clients. Ernestina belongs to a Trust Bank group called “Adom Bi Apue.” The members in the group guarantee each other's loans.

loans.use: To buy flour, sugar, and margarine in bulk

loans.name: Nelsa Margarita

texts.en:
Nelsa is a member of the Bonanza Village Bank. Nelsa is 38 years old and lives with her partner and their two daughters. Nelsa bakes traditional Peruvian breads in her parents’ oven, as do her siblings. She works seven days a week, and sells her bread in the Santa Clara Market in the afternoon. Nelsa needs a loan of 600 soles to buy lard and sugar. Nelsa dreams of owning a large store and a chicken restaurant and that her children will graduate from college with professional degrees.

Translated from Spanish by Cynthia McMurry, Kiva fellow: Nelsa es socia del Banco Comunal Bonanza. Nelsa es conviviente, tiene 38 años y 2 hijas, Nelsa se dedica a la elaboración de panes típicos que elabora en el horno que era de sus padres, en el cual también elaboran panes sus hermanos, actividad que realiza todos los días y lo vende en el mercado Santa Clara por las tardes. Nelsa necesita un préstamo de 600 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de manteca y azúcar. Nelsa sueña con tener una tienda grande, una polleria y que sus hijos sean profesionales.

loans.use: To buy sugar and lard to bake bread.

loans.name: Naheed Aziz Ahmad Group

texts.en:
My name is Naheed, and I am a 46-year-old lady. I completed my education up to 10th standard. I have been living in this city for the past 15 years. My husband name is A. A., and he is a farmer. I am the mother of two kids: one daughter and one son. My daughter's name is Mahak Sitara. Mahak is in 8th standard.

My son has a mobile phone shop where he sells and repairs mobile phones. I work in a decorative embroidery business. I have 6 years' experience in this business. I use my earnings to pay the school fees of my daughter. I have successfully repaid my two loans from Asasah (a micro-finance institution in Pakistan). Now I am applying for a loan to buy more handsets to grow my son’s mobile phone business.

I am the group leader for a few more women in my locality. Bushra baji wants a loan to buy biscuits and candies wholesale to sell in various shops. Saima baji wants a loan to buy fertilizer to re-sell. Bashiran baji wants a loan to buy wooden beams for her shuttering business. Shamim Akhtar baji and Noreen baji each want a loan to change the body of their auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle).

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy more phone handsets to re-sell

loans.name: Yobana

texts.en:
Yobana is a member of the Bonanza Village Bank. Yobana is 26 years old and lives with her partner; they do not yet have any children. Yobana runs a tavern, which is located in a rented space on a central street in the city of Ayacucho. She works seven days a week, with the help of one employee.

Yobana and her partner also have a store where they sell computers and offer computer repair services. Yobana needs a loan of 1050 soles, which she will use to buy beer. Yobana’s dreams are to have her own clothing store and to expand her businesses.

Translated from Spanish by Cynthia McMurry, Kiva Fellow

Yobana es socia del Banco Comunal Bonanza. Yobana es conviviente, tiene 26 años y aun no tiene hijos, Yobana tiene una taberna en un local alquilado ubicado en una calle céntrica, actividad que realiza todos los días con la ayuda de 1 personal.

Además Yobana junto a su pareja tienen una tienda de venta de computadoras y mantenimiento. Yovana necesita un préstamo de 1050 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de cerveza. Los sueños de Yovana son tener una tienda de venta de ropas y ampliar sus negocios.

loans.use: Buy beer for re-sale

loans.name: Timotea

texts.en:
Timotea is a member of the Azucenas (“White Lilies”) Village Bank. She is 48 years old and married with six children. Timotea is an artisan; she makes alabaster sculptures such as candlesticks and small animals. Timotea’s son helps her make the sculptures, which she sells from her stand in the Ex-Penal Market, an old jail near the center of Ayacucho that has been converted into an artisan’s market in which each artisan has their own small space in what used to be a jail cell. Timotea works at her stand seven days a week.

Timotea is requesting a loan of 1,800 soles to buy more materials to make her sculptures with. She has been a FINCA client for more than twelve years now. Timotea also works with FINCA Perú Exports, making alabaster sculptures for export.

On FINCA Perú Exports’s website, you can read about Timotea and her family’s brave escape from Shining Path terrorists in the late 1970s: http://www.fincaperuexports.org/timotea.html and see some of her work: http://www.fincaperuexports.org/alabaster stone.html

loans.use: Buy more materials for alabaster sculptures

loans.name: Demetria

texts.en:
Demetria is a member of the Universo (“Universe”) Village Bank. Demetria is 54 years old and is married with six children. Demetria owns her own stand in the Nery Garcia Market, where she sells vegetables in bulk and by the kilo. She buys her vegetables from local farmers with the help of her daughter.

Demetria needs a loan of 3000 soles to buy onions and carrots. Demetria’s dreams are for her children to grow up to be working professionals and to improve her business.

Translated from Spanish by Cynthia McMurry, Kiva Fellow

Demetria es socia del Banco Comunal Universo. Demetria es casada, tiene 54 años y 6 hijos, Demetria tiene un puesto propio en el mercado Nery García en donD. venD. verduras al por mayor y menor, sus productos los adquiere D. los mismos productores, actividad que realiza con la ayuda D. su hija.

Demetria necesita un préstamo D. 3000 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra D. cebolla, zanahoria. Los sueños D. Demetria son que sus hijos sean profesionales, mejorar su negocio.

loans.use: Buy onions and carrots

loans.name: Jose Gabriel

texts.es:
El Señor de nombre José Gabriel P. L. tiene la edad de 57 años, su estado civil es soltero, este Señor tiene 8 hijos de los cuales solo 1 de sus hijos depende de el y tiene la edad de 21 años y cursa recientemente el 5 año de su carrera mercadotecnia, en sus deseos son lograr que su hijo supere su nivel educacional para que el día de mañana se un gran profesional en su carrera, sus propósitos son de darle mejoras a su taller ya que este es su lugar de trabajo por lo que es necesario efectuarle mejoras para proporcionar comodidad y calidad a sus clientes además esta el acondicionar a si vivienda para el bienestar propio y de su familia.


Su actividad económica es la de soldador, la ubicación de su negocio es en el reparto  Julián reyes ½ cuadra arriba, el tiempo que tiene de poseer este negocio es de 30 años, el inicio este negocio por cuenta propia decide aprender este oficio en un taller llamado
Alonso a la edad de 15 años y es aquí donde encuentra su medio de trabajo y a la edad de 20 años decide instalar su propio negocio y obtiene a sus clientes por amigos y vecinos que sabían que trabaja a la perfección, el financiamiento es para capital de trabajo asignado para la compra de herramientas que son necesarias para su taller como lo son: compresor, portapower, emeril ya que tiene que realizar la compra de estas en lugar donde resulten mas favorable y sus clientes se muestren satisfechos con su trabajo.
texts.en:
Señor José Gabriel P. L. is 57 and single. He has 8 children, of whom only one is still his dependent. This son is 21 and is in his fifth year of studying marketing. One of his dreams is to see his son increase his level of education so one day he will be a great professional. His goals are to make some improvements to his workshop since it is necessary to give better comfort and quality to his customers. He would also like to fix up his house for his own well-being and that of his family. He is a welder, and his business is located in the Julián Reyes neighborhood half a block up the road. He has owned this business for 30 years. He started it with his own funds when he decided to learn the welding trade. His workshop is called Alonso. When he was 15, he found his line of work, and at age 20, he decided to start his own business. He made his friends and neighbors his customers, who knew that he works for perfection. This financing will be used for working capital to purchase tools he needs for his workshop such as a compressor and a Porta Power kit. He needs to purchase these things so he will have favorable results and so his customers will be satistified with his work.

Translated from Spanish by Tanya Harper, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working capital

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Francisca

texts.en:
Francisca is a member of the Universo (“Universe”) Village Bank. Francisca is 40 years old and is married with four children. Francisca travels to various regional markets to sell vegetables and fruits. She buys grains, cheese, hens, and eggs at the regional markets, then brings them to markets in the city of Ayacucho to re-sell.

Francisca needs a loan of 1000 soles to buy vegetables and fruits. Francisca’s dreams are for her children to finish their schooling and to improve her home and her business.

Translated from Spanish by Cynthia McMurry, Kiva Fellow

Francisca es socia del Banco Comunal Universo. Francisca es casada, tiene 50 años y 4 hijos, Francisca viaja a las diferentes ferias de la región en donde vende verduras, frutas y de las ferias compra cereales, queso, gallina, huevos que luego comercializa en los mercados de la ciudad de Ayacucho.

Francisca necesita un préstamo de 1000 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de verduras y frutas. Los sueños de Francisca son que sus hijos culminen sus estudios, mejorar su casa y negocio.

loans.use: Buy vegetables and fruits

loans.name: Libia

texts.en:
Libia is a member of the Universo (Universe) Village Bank. She is 48 years old, married, and has five children. Libia has a stand at the Abastos Market in the city of Ayacucho, where she sells different kinds of vegetables, both in bulk and per kilo. She and her son buy the vegetables from local farmers. Libia needs a loan of 2400 soles to buy onions and carrots. Her dreams are for her children to grow up to be working professionals and to improve her business. 

 
Translated from Spanish by Cynthia McMurry, Kiva fellow
Libia es socia del Banco Comunal Universo. 
Libia es casada, tiene 48 años y 5 hijos, Libia tiene un puesto en el mercado de abastos de la ciudad de Ayacucho en donde vende verduras variadas al por mayor y menor, sus productos los adquiere de los productores, actividad que realiza con la ayuda de su hijo. 
Libia necesita un préstamo de 2400 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de cebolla y zanahoria. 
Los sueños de Libia son que sus hijos sean profesionales y mejorar su negocio.

loans.use: Buy onions and carrots

loans.name: Maura Rosa

texts.es:
La Señora Maura Rosa C. tiene la edad de 47 años, su estado civil es casada, Doña Maura tiene 3 hijos sus edades son las siguientes su hijo mayor de 23 años es licenciado en ciencias actuariales, su hija de 22 años cursa el 4 año de la carrera de licenciatura en ciencias sociales y su otro hijo de 15 años y cursa el 5 año de secundaria, su esposo labora como chofer, los deseos de Doña Maura para con su negocio es incrementar mas el monto de su financiamiento para obtener mas capital de trabajo y llevar a cabo sus propósitos, en sus sueños esta que la institución crezca lo suficiente para llegar a superar la pobreza que tenemos en el país.


 
La actividad económica a la que se dedica es venta de cosméticos, la ubicación de su negocio es de forma ambulante, el tiempo que tiene de poseer su negocio es de 2 años, ella inicia este negocio con una pulpería y la mantuvo activa alrededor de 2 años, pero debido a que Doña Maura posee su trabajo de enfermera en el hospital por lo que la pulpería era su otra fuente de ingresos pero esta no la pudo mantener activo debido a que llegaba muy cansada de su trabajo y decide por cuenta propia realizar la venta de cosméticos y es así como con este negocio se forma su medio de trabajo por lo que este le ayuda con los compromisos contraídos para salir adelante, el financiamiento es para capital de trabajo por lo que necesita realizar la compra de sus productos en las diferentes casas comerciales ya que en estos días festivos ha recibido mucho pedidos y quiere satisfacer la demanda de sus clientes.
texts.en:
Maura Rosa C. is 47 years old, married, and has three children. Her oldest son is 23 and has a degree in actuarial science, her daughter is 22 and is in her fourth year of studying social sciences at the university, and her other son is 15 and is in his 5th year of high school. Her husband is a chauffeur. Maura hopes to get increased financing for her business so that she has more working capital to carry out her plans. She dreams of the institution growing large enough to overcome the country's poverty. She sells cosmetics as a street vendor, a business she has had for 2 years. She started it as a neighborhood store and kept that for about 2 years. But because Maura is a hospital nurse and the store was her second source of income, she could not maintain it because she was tired after work. She decided to sell cosmetics, and with this business she finds the means to meet her obligations. This loan is for working capital so she can buy products from various merchants. She has received many orders during this Christmas season and wants to satisfy her customers' requests.

Translated from Spanish by Kelly Wester, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Juana Lucila

texts.en:
Juana is a member of the Universo (Universe) Village Bank.  She is 50 years old, married, and has four children. Juana sells sweets from a cart in the bus terminal of a local transportation company. She works seven days a week. She also cleans and takes care of the terminal in exchange for the right to sell her products insiD.. Juana needs a loan of 1000 soles to buy soda, cookies, and caramels. Her dreams are to improve her home, to have a store of her own in a fixed location, and for her children to grow up to be working professionals. 


Translated from Spanish by Cynthia McMurry, Kiva fellow
Juana es socia del Banco Comunal Universo. 
Juana es casada, tiene 50 años y 4 hijos, Juana venD. golosinas en el terminal terrestre D. una empresa D. transportes, para lo cual cuenta con una carreta, actividad que realiza todos los días. Juana además realiza la limpieza y cuidado del terminal a cambio D. vender sus productos. 
Juana necesita un préstamo D. 1000 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra D. gaseosas, galletas y caramelos. 
Los sueños D. Juana son mejorar su casa, tener una tienda estable y que sus hijos sean profesionales.

loans.use: Buy soda, cookies, and caramels

loans.name: Cirila

texts.en:
Cirila is a member of the Universo (Universe) Village Bank. Cirila, 42, is married and has four children. She sells fruit outside the bus station of a local inter-provincial transport company. Between November and April, she sells boxes of prickly pears (“tunas”) from the same location. She works seven days per week, with the help of her children.  Cirila needs a loan of 2600 soles to buy prickly pears and other fruits.  Her dreams are to educate her children so that they get ahead in life, to improve her business, and to open a store in her home. 


Translated from Spanish by Cynthia McMurry, Kiva fellow
Cirila es socia del Banco Comunal Universo. 
Cirila es casada, tiene 42 años y 4 hijos, Cirila vende frutas en la puerta de un terminal terrestre interprovincial, en los meses de noviembre a abril vende tuna por cajas en el mismo lugar, actividad que realiza todos los días con la ayuda de sus hijos. 
Cirila necesita un préstamo de 2600 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de tuna y frutas variadas. 
Los sueños de Cirila son educar a sus hijos para que salgan adelante, mejorar su negocio y tener una tienda en su casa.

loans.use: Buy prickly pears and other fruits

loans.name: Jeronima Esperanza

texts.es:
El Nombre de la Señora Jerónima Esperanza B. tiene la edad de 62 años, su estado civil es casada, Doña Jerónima tiene 8 hijos y ninguno de sus hijos depende de ella ya que todos trabajan por cuneta propia, su compañero de vida no labora, sus propósitos son mantener activo su negocio ya que esta es su mayor fuente de ingresos, sus deseos son de mejorar cada día en la calidad de sus tortillas para que de esta forma pueda obtener mas clientes, sus sueños son mantener su negocio activo para tener oportunidad de sacar adelante a su familia y el día de mañana tenga algo con que sostenerse.


Su actividad económica es la venta y la elaboración de tortillas, la ubicación de su negocio es del colegio del INO 1 cuadra arriba, el tiempo que tiene de poseer su negocio es de 40 años, su negocio inicia por cuenta propia ya que no tenia un trabajo estable que le proporcionara ingresos y su Mama le había enseñado este tipo de oficio por lo que se convierte en un medio de trabajo para ella y decide comenzar con medio quintal de maíz y con el paso del tiempo consigue fama de vender tortillas y por sus vecinos y otras personas se gana a sus clientes por lo que decide que este seria su negocio, el financiamiento es para capital de trabajo ya que tiene que comprar leña, maíz y comal que es el utensilio para la elaboración de sus tortillas.
texts.en:
Mrs. Jerónima Esperanza B. is 62 years old and married. She has 8 children, none of whom depend on her since they are all now self employed. Her husband does not work. Jerónima´s purpose is to keep her business active since it is her most important source of income. Her wish is to daily improve the quality of her tortillas, in order to capture more clients. Her dream is to keep her business active so that she has the opportunity to move her family ahead and to have a way to support herself in the future. Her business is the preparation and sale of tortillas. She has been in this business for 40 years. She started her own business because she did not have a stable job with which to support herself. Her mother had taught her this trade, so she converted it into a means of work for herself and decided to begin with 50 kg of corn. As time passed she grew famous for her tortillas and brought in new clients through her neighbors and other people. That was when she decided she would make tortillas her business. The financing will provide working capital since she needs to buy firewood, corn and a ceramic griddle, which are the tools she uses to make her tortillas.

Translated from Spanish by Erin Corcoran, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: working capital

loans.name: Maria Elena

texts.en:
Maria is a member of the Universo (Universe) Village Bank.  Maria, 55, is married, and has seven children. Maria travels to different markets around the Ayacucho Region twice a week to sell fruits, vegetables, and dry goods. She buys animals like cows at these regional markets to resell in the San Juan Bautista Sunday Market in the city of Ayacucho.  Maria needs a loan of 2000 soles to buy rice, sugar, pasta, and soda. Maria dreams of opening a large store in her home, so that she won’t have to travel any more. 

Translated from Spanish by Cynthia McMurry, Kiva fellow
Maria es socia del Banco Comunal Universo. 
Maria es casada, tiene 55 años y 7 hijos, Maria viaja a las diferentes ferias D. la región D. Ayacucho, 2 veces por semana en donD. venD. frutas, verduras, abarrotes y D. las ferias compra animales como ganado vacuno, que luego venD. en la feria D. San Juan Bautista. 
Maria necesita un préstamo D. 2000 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra D. arroz, azúcar, fideo, gaseosas. 
Maria sueña con tener una tienda granD. en su casa y no tener que viajar mas.

loans.use: Buy rice, sugar, pasta. and soda

loans.name: Arcenia

texts.es:
Arcenia, tiene 48 años  es separada con dos hijos  mayores de edad y profesionales, con sus familias formadas e independiente de ella. La misma se dedica a la venta de comestible como por ejemplo: empandas, marineras, milanesas croquetas y todo tipo de comidas rápidas.


Arcenia  se ha dedicado a este rubro por más de dos años y su local comercial se encuentra en la zona del km 9 Acaray donde da de comer por día a 53 clientes debido a que su comida es la más rica en la zona.

 
Arcenia, con sus ganancias de las ventas hace frente a los gastos de la casa y también recibe el apoyo de sus hijos que le pasan una mensualidad.





Arcenia, comenta que tiene bastante venta. Es por ello que  desea adquirir mayor cantidad de mercaderías como frutas, verduras, productos cárnicos, arroz, aceite, azúcar, etc., de este modo podrá abastecer la fuerte demanda que tiene en la zona y tener mayor cantidad de clientes.
texts.en:
Arcenia is 48 years old, separated, and has 2 grown children who are professionals with their own families and no longer dependent upon her. She sells food such as: turnovers, fried, breaded meat and croquettes and other types of rapidly-prepared food. Arcenia has been preparing food for over two years and her business is located at the kilometer 9 Acaray area where she prepares food every day for 53 customers as her food is the most delicious in the area. Arcenia, with her profits from her sales, pays her household expenses and also receives support from her children who give her a some money monthly. Arcenia says that she has enough sales. So she wishes to acquire a large quantity of merchandise such as fruit, vegetables, meat products, rice, oil, sugar, etc. and in this way she will be able to meet the strong demand that she has in this area and have a greater number of customers.

Translated from Spanish by Cindy Kendall, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy groceries such as rice, sugar, oil, vegetables, fruit, baked goods, meat

loans.name: María Emilia

texts.es:
Maria, tiene 40 años  está acompañada con  el señor   Pablo Riveros que trabaja como seguridad privada y es  madre de cuatro hijos, de los cuales tres aun son criaturas y dependen de sus padres y uno que es mayor de edad y trabaja de forma independiente. 
Ella se dedica a la venta de todo tipo de mercaderías como ser ropas y zapatos, remeras, blusas, jeans, pantalones, championes, sandalias entre otros.

Maria se ha dedicado a este rubro por más de dos años y su local comercial se encuentra en su misma casa, dónde para esto, realizo algunas modificaciones para poder tener el espacio correspondiente para su salón comercial.

Maria, con sus ganancias de las ventas aporta a los ingresos de la casa, y junto con su compañero hacen frente a los gastos  familiares.

Maria, comenta que tiene muy buena  venta. Es por ello que ella desea adquirir mayor cantidad de ropas de la temporada primavera - verano, de este modo podrá abastecer la fuerte demanda que tiene en la zona donde sale a hacer su venta.
texts.en:
Maria is 40 years old and is partnered with Pablo Riveros who works as a private security guard. She has four children, of whom three are still young and dependent on their parents and one who is an adult and is working. She sells a variety of merchandise such as clothing and shoes, shirts, blouses, jeans, pants, slippers, sandals among others. Maria has been in this business for more than two years and she sells out of her home, to which she had to make modifications in order to be able to have the space she needed for her commercial enterprise. Maria contributes to household income with the revenues for her sales, and together with her partner she shares the household expenses. Maria tells us that sales are good. Because of this, she wants to acquire more Spring and Summer clothing so that she will be ready for the strong demand from her customers.

Translated from Spanish by Laure Kwon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy clothing and shoes for ladies, men, and children

loans.name: Miryan

texts.es:
Mirian, tiene 40 años  es soltera con una hija que es menor de edad y  dependiente de ella,  solo estudia por el momento. Ella se dedica a la venta de zapatos, championes y ropas.
Mirian  se ha dedicado a este rubro por más de dos años y su local comercial se encuentra en la zona del mercado de abasto de ciudad del este. Todo empezó como un negocio familiar  hicieron una sociedad con su hermana donde invirtieron capital para montar su negocio, hoy día la hermana de la misma le vendió toda sus acciones quedando ella como única propietaria del local comercial. 
Mirian, con sus ganancias de las ventas  hace frente a los gastos de la casa y ayuda a su hija en sus estudios para que en el día de mañana la nena sea una gran profesional.
Mirian, comenta que tiene bastante venta. Es por ello que  desea adquirir mayor cantidad de ropas primavera - verano y championes deportivos, y así  abastecer la fuerte demanda que tiene en la zona.
texts.en:
Miryan is 40 years old and single. She has a daughter, still a minor, who is dependent on her and is a full time student at the moment. Miryan works sells shoes, running shoes and clothing. Miryan has worked in this business sector for more than 2 years. Her business is located in the zone near her city´s wholesale market. It all began as a family business when Miryan and her sister formed a company together and invested the money with which Miryan would launch her business. Her sister has now sold all of her shares to Miryan, leaving her the sole proprietor of the business. With the earnings she receives from her sales, Miryan takes care of the household expenses and helps her daughter with her studies so that one day her daughter will be a great professional. Miryan comments that she has plenty of sales. For this reason she wants to acquire a larger quantity of spring and summer clothing and sports shoes, as a way of stocking up to meet the strong demand she sees for these products.

Translated from Spanish by Erin Corcoran, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy clothing and shoes for women, men and children.

loans.name: Pedro

texts.es:
Pedro, tiene 44 años está acompañado con la señora Edita Ortigoza que es ama de casa, tienen cuatro hijos todos menores de edad y dependientes de sus padres. El señor se dedica a la venta ambulante de todo tipo de mercaderías como por ejemplo: sabanas, colchas, termos, latonas, etc.



Pedro, se dedica a este rubro desde  hace más de siete años su depósito se encuentra en su casa  donde guarda sus mercaderías. Tiene formado quinientos clientes aproximadamente en toda la zona de ciudad del este, la ciudad de franco y Hernandarias, lo cual da trabajo a dos personas más que trabajan como cobradores  y así también ayuda a las personas de su barrio dándole trabajo.






Pedro, comenta que tiene bastante demanda de sus mercaderías es por ello que él desea adquirir mayor cantidad y nuevas variedades como toallas, cacerolas, edredones, ollas, etc., para abastecer la fuerte demanda que tiene y así también generar mayor ingreso para él y fuente de trabajo en la zona.
texts.en:
Pedro is 44 years old and lives with Edita Ortigoza, who is a housewife. They have four children, all under 18 and dependent on their parent. Pedro works selling all sorts of merchandise through the streets, including sheets, bedspreads, thermoses, bowls, etc.

Pedro has been working in this business sector for more than seven years. His warehouse is located in his home, where he stores his merchandise. He has approximately 500 clients throughout his city, the city of Franco and Hernandarias. He is able to give work to 2 additional people who work as collectors and in this way help the people of his neighborhood by giving them work.

Pedro comments that he has plenty of demand for his merchandise. Recognizing that demand, he wants to acquire a larger quantity and wider variety of items such as towels, saucepans, comforters, cooking pots, etc., in order to stock up to meet the strong demand while generating more earnings for him and more work for the people of his neighborhood.

Translated from Spanish by Erin Corcoran, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of saucepans, frying pans, comforters and towels.

loans.name: Santiago

texts.es:
Santiago , tiene 48 años  está casado con  la señora  Mariana de S. y juntos tienen cuatro hijos de los cuales dos son mayores de edad, trabajan en el  centro de ciudad del este como asalariados y los otros dos son menores de edad que van todavía a la escuela, uno de ellos que es un varón de quince  años,  es el que sigue el trabajo de su papa después de llegar de la escuela por la tarde acompaña a su padre en sus ventas diarias, venden cigarrillos de todas la marcas por ejemplo: Kentuki, Kent, Philips Morris, Marlboro entre otros.

Santiago se ha dedicado a este rubro por más de ocho años, el comenta que por la mañana sale a levantar los pedidos por toda la zona en despensas, supermercados, kioscos, etc. Y por la tarde hace la entrega de las mercaderías en su furgón que pudo comprar con el dinero  que ahorraba de este trabajo. 

Santiago, con sus ganancias de las ventas aporta a los ingresos de la casa,  junto con su señora y  también con la ayuda de sus hijos hacen frente a los gastos  familiares.

Santiago, comenta que tiene bastante venta. Es por ello que  desea adquirir mayor cantidad  de mercaderías especialmente de la marca Kent y Kentucky ya que son sus mercaderías estrellas  de este modo podrá abastecer la fuerte demanda que tiene en la zona donde sale a hacer su venta.
texts.en:
Santiago is 48 years old, is married to Mariana de S. and together they have four children of which two are adults. They work in the center of Ciudad del Este as salaried workers and the other two younger children are still in school. One of them is a 15 year old male helps his father with the business after school in the afternoon by accompanying him on his daily sales, selling cigarettes of all brands, for example: Kentuki, Kent, Philips Morris, Marlboro among others. Santiago has dedicated himself to this work for more than eight years. He says that in the morning he fills requests for all the local stores, supermarket and kiosks. In the afternoon he delivers the merchandise in his van which he was able to purchase from money saved from this job. Santiago uses his profits to support the household and, together with his wife, also help their children with family costs. Santiago says that sales are going very well. Because of this, he would like to acquire a larger amount of merchandise, especially Kent and Kentucky brands that are his star products. In this manner he will be able to meet the strong demand that his products have in the area and make his sales.

Translated from Spanish by Erin Corcoran, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Compra de cigarrillos.

loans.name: Acuario Rsr Group

texts.es: El Grupo  ACUARIO RSR esta representado por la señora Luzmila. Este Banco tiene doce componentes que en su mayoría radican en la Zona Villa Caluyo D. la ciudad del Alto, el grupo tiene un nivel D. vida regular, estas señoras son en su mayoría comerciantes D. diferentes productos como la venta venta D. comida, abarrotes, chompas, mantas y prendas D. vestir tejidas a mano y macramé. Ellas necesitan el crédito para aumentar su capital D. trabajo y Stoker sus mercaderías, viendo la posibilidad D. crecimiento por las fechas naviD.ñas en la cual existe mayor demanda del mercado, siempre existe la competencia pero no tienen importancia cuando se tiene la lealtad D. sus compradores y la fuerza del trabajo del grupo. Los miembros del grupo ingresan al tercer ciclo por lo que gozan D. experiencia en grupos solidarios prevaleciendo la responsabilidad y el cumplimiento en los pagos D. anteriores ciclos.
texts.en:
The ACUARIO RSR group is represented by Luzmila. This bank is maD. up of 12 additional people who are mainly from the Zona Villa Caluyo area of the town of Alto. The group has an average standard of living. These women are for the most part traders of various products such as food sales, groceries, sweaters, blankets, hand-woven clothing and macrame. They need a loan in order to increase their working capital and increase their stock of merchandise as they see an opportunity for growth with the holiday season when demand is greatest. There is always competitition but they are not concerned as they have loyal clients and each other's strength. The members of this group are beginning their third cycle. They have experienced group solidarity and payment compliance in previous loan cycles.

Translated from Spanish by Laure Kwon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Capital de Operaciones

loans.name: Las Conquistadoras Group

texts.es: El grupo las Conquistadoras estan representados por la señora Rose Marie y conformado por 12 personas en su mayoría son mujeres, demuestran solidaridad y compromiso con cada una D. las integrantes del grupo. La s Socias se dedican a la venta D. hortalizas, chompas tejidas a mano, artesanías, comida repuestos, mantas, ropas y al servicio D. prótesis dental. La socias saben que existe la competencia en el mercado en especial en sus rubros pero el nivel competitivo y las ganas D. trabajar D. cada una D. las socias siempre las saca adelante. el destino del financiamiento es para la compra D. mercadería e insumos para mejorar su mercadería y hacerse mas competitivas en el mercado. Las socias ya tiene experiencia en grupos solidarios ya que se encuentran cursando su cuarto ciclo el cual culminan siendo cumplidas y responsables en sus pagos.
texts.en:
The group called the "Conquistadoras" is represented by señora Rose Marie and is formed of 12 people, the majority of whom are women. They demonstrate support and commitment with each member of the group. The members sell vegetables, hand-woven sweaters, crafts, food, blankets, clothing, and one has a denture service. The members know that competition exists in the market, especially in their trades, but the competitiveness and willingness to work of each one of the members let them get ahead. This financing will be used to purchase merchandise and supplies to better their merchandise and make themselves more competitive in the market. The members have experience in support groups and are starting their fourth loan, and they will finish it by complying with and being responsible with their payments.

Translated from Spanish by Tanya Harper, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Operating capital

loans.name: Grupo Bolivia Group

texts.es: Grupo GRUPO BOLIVIA se integra mediante una asociacion D. comerciante que esta ubicada en pleno centro D. la ciudad D. La Paz, llamada  "Feria D. Boliva" por lo cual se creo el nombre del banco comunal, entre las socias existen diferentes tipos D. negocios como ser el D. la presidenta la señora Mirianh quien se dedica a la venta D. perfumes el resto D. los socios (as) se dedican al actividades como la venta D. ropa, calzados, cosmeticos, libros y computadoras. El mercado esta lleno D. personas que te ofrecen productos D. consumo pero ellas ofrecen calidad y variedad D. productos a bajos precios es por eso que no temem a la competencia. El destino del Crédito es para la compra D. mercadería y para la mejora D. sus puestos D. trabajo ya que el cliente exige mejores condiciones para atenderlo en mejores condiciones. Los socios (as) tiene experiencia en grupos solidarios por los trabjos en otras entidades financieras pero contando con muy buienos antecedentes crediticios la Fundación agrocapital les brina la oportuinidad D. mejoras su calidad D. vida y la D. sus familias.
texts.en:
The Bolivia Group was created through a merchant association located in the center of the city of La Paz called Feria D. Boliva (Market of Bolivia) which led to the name of the Village Bank. The group members participate in various types of businesses like that of the group president Miranh who sells perfume. The other group members work in such activities as the sales of clothing, shoes, cosmetics, books and computers. The market is full of people who offer consumable products but these women offer a variety of high quality products at low prices so they don't fear the competition. The purpose of this loan is to purchase merchandise and to improve their work stands since their customers demand to be attended in better conditions. The group members have experience in support groups since they have participated in other financial entities; since they have a good credit record, the Agrocapital Foundation offers them the opportunity to improve their and their families' quality of life.

Translated from Spanish by Scott Crandall, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Las Semillitas De Rsr Group

texts.es: El grupo "Las Semillitas D. RSR" están representadas por el señor Raúl Alberto, esta conformado por personas que residen en el mismo barrio, los miembros del grupo se dedican al comercio D. productos como embutidos, ropa, zapatos, abarrotes en tiendas D. barrio y al transporte público, son gente trabajadora que sabe que existe la competencia y que depenD. D. el esfuerzo y la dedicación que uno pone en su trabajo para salir adelante, El destino del crédito es para el incremento D. mercadería y la adquisición D. productos nuevos para la época naviD.ña que es donD. existe mayor movimiento D. productos a la venta. La mayoría D. los socios (as)  tienen experiencia en grupos solidarios por lo que saben que se necesita responsabilidad y compromiso para salir adelante como lo dice su nombre son semillitas del progreso para mejorar la vida D. sus familias.
texts.en:
The "Las Semillitas D. RSR" (Little Seeds of RSR) Group are represented by Raul Alberto and is maD. up of people that live in the same neighborhood. The group members sell products like meats, clothing, shoes, and groceries in their small neighborhood general stores and proviD. public transport services. They are hard-working people who know that there is a great deal of competition so their success depends on how much effort and dedication each puts into their work. The purpose of the loan is to increase their inventory and acquire new products for the Christmas season which is when they have the most sales. Most of the group members have experience in support groups so they are familiar with the responsibility and commitment necessary to progress; as their name says, these are seeds of progress that will improve the lives of their families.

Translated from Spanish by Scott Crandall, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Mr. Sun Sout Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Sixteen people who live in Phum Soupy Village in Kampong Chhnang Province have formed a group and have requested a village bank loan. They will use the loan for different purposes.

Mr. S. S. is the village bank loan president, and he is a vet who makes a small income to support the family. Aside from this business, he breeds pigs. Since this business is going well, he wants to expand it, so Mr. S. S. decided to ask for a loan to buy three more pigs for breeding. His wife, Mrs. El Sum, is a housewife who cooks the delicious food for the family. Mr. S. S. is 28 years old and the father of two children who are too young to work or study because they are two and four years old. All of the members of the group are present in the picture, except for two at the back who are blocked.

All of the members in this group loan are end-of-term loans so they are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK’s main product because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia’s poor. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK’s clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To buy three more pigs for breeding.

loans.name: Thoun's Group

texts.en: Mrs. Thoun N. is a group leader of four who all live in Ta Reab Doun Sar village in Kandal province. She sells cakes in the local market. Since her business is going well, she wants to expand it; thus, she decided to ask for a loan to buy ingredients to make the cakes. She hopes to increase her income and improve their living conditions with this loan. Her husband, Mr. Mel Tha, is a tractor driver. Aside from this career, he is also a construction worker. Mrs. Thoun N. is a 44-year old mother with three children who attend the local school.

loans.use: To buy ingredients to make cakes.

loans.name: Sary's Group

Since her business is going well, she wants to expand it; thus, she decided to request a loan to buy more fish for her business. She hopes to increase her income and provide a better life for her family. Her husband, Mr. Sao Kouy, is a driver. Mrs. Sary C. is 33 years old and the mother of four children, three of whom are attending the local school, while the other is only three years old.

One of the group members, Mrs. Leng K., could not be in the picture, so her husband is pictured instead.  

This is a village bank loan consisting of mainly end-of-term loans. Four members have end-of-term loans and the rest of have monthly payment loans. These members are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term ( EoT) loans are AMK’s main product because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia’s poor. It allows them to repay portions of principal whenever they are financially able to. Most clients start to make their payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK’s clients make their payments on time.

loans.use: To buy more fish for her business.

P. was selected by the group to be the village bank president. She sells chickens in the market. This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

In order to improve their living conditions, Mrs. Liem P. decided to ask for a loan to buy a cow to start a breeding business. She hopes to increase her income after she sells her cow. Mrs. Liem P. is a widow with two children, one of whom is a laborer while the youngest one attends the local school.

texts.en:

Mrs. Boeurn M. is the village bank president, selected by the members. She is 52 years old and the mother of two children who help their parents in their business activities.  Mrs. Boeurn M. is a farmer who owns 1 hectare where she grows rice. Her husband is a palm juice collector who gathers juice to process into palm sugar and wine. He is also a pig breeder. Since this business is going well, he wants to expand it.  So Mrs. Boeurn M. decided to ask for a loan to buy three more piglets for her husband's business.

This is a village bank loan consisting mainly of end-of-term loans. Six members have end-of-term loans, and the rest have monthly payment loans. loans.name: Mrs. Nan Thoang Village Bank Group

texts.en:
This village bank, which consists of 18 people, is located in O’Kandol Village in Kampong Chhnang Province. Mrs. Nan T. is the village bank president, selected by the members. She is 44 years old and the mother of six children, two of whom are construction workers while the others are attending the local school. Mrs. Nan T. sells pots in the local village. She is also a farmer who owns 0.5 hectare where she cultivates rice. She can earn only a little revenue from rice because her plot of land is small. In order to expand her rice revenue, Mrs. Nan T. decided to ask for a loan to add to her savings to buy another piece of land on which to cultivate rice. Her husband, Mr. Kem Samart, is a fisherman who catches fish to support the family. 

All the members in this village bank loan will receive end-of-term loans, so they are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK’s main product because they are the most beneficial to Cambodia’s poor. These loans allow borrowers to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to do so. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK’s clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% overall, and a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To add to her savings to buy another piece of land on which to cultivate rice.

loans.name: Mr. Nan Phen Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Sixteen people who live in O’Kandol Village in Kampong Chhnang Province are members of the village bank that is requesting this loan. Each of the bank members plans to use their loan for a different purpose. 

Mr. Nan P., the village bank president, is a motorbike taxi driver. He now faces a problem because his motorbike is too old, and he needs to spend a lot of money on petroleum. To deal with this problem, Mr. Nan P. has decided to ask for a loan to buy a new motorbike, and he hopes to save some money this way. 

His wife, Mrs. Mao Sareth, is a housewife who cooks delicious food for the family. Mr. Nan P. is 44 years old and the father of three children. One of his children is employed in a garment factory. The others attend the local school. 

Mr. Samban S. does not come to the loan meeting, but his wife came, S. she is presented in the picture instead of her husband.
